Downey Jr. and Duvall share some nice moments together whether they are bickering or enjoying each other's company, but as solo turns there is nothing much to ride home about. It's hard to pinpoint how such a varied cast (which includes Vera Farmiga, Vincent D'Onofrio and Billy Bob Thornton), a decent story set up and a pedigree production could produce such good but disappointingly average final product.The Judge perhaps needed a wiser head to adjudicate it's makings, Dobkin seemingly struggling with his newly found dramatic mojo, as it's not hard to see why The Judge became such a non-event upon release that has seen it disappear from memory, awards shows and critics minds mere months after it was a golden child of the hype train. As someone said to me, "I can see The Judge being played on mid-day TV in a few years' time" which is a verdict that perfectly sums up the crimes of a film that could have been so much more had it mastered anyone of its countless ambitions. Harsh judgements these maybe, but when you've got something that looks good on paper, the expectations come with it.3 hosing offs out of 5 For more movie reviews and opinions check into -www.jordanandeddie.wordpress.com

The judge is a drama about the broken relationship between a father and a son, as it is revealed bit by bit as we watch Hank (the son) trying to discover if his father, the judge, committed murder, as the police suspect him to. The truth is that you don't see how the real story is revealed, until the movie it's finally over and you have time to think it over. The main, superficial story is that Hank returns home for his mother's funeral and end ups defending his father in court. But, apart from that, there is an other story that slowly emerges, the story of the relationship between Hank and his father, Hank's past, his ex girlfriend and his currant family stage. Except from the excellent technique in the story presentation, the movie also has great performances, especially by Robert Downey Jr. The little kid was a good surprise also. However, there are some parts of the film that bothered me. The ending it was too obvious, but maybe it couldn't be other way. The stories were too many, so if they kept at least one off the film, it would have been nice. Other than that it was an enjoyable film that I might watch again some time, so 7 out of 10.

In this film, a son who graduated as a lawyer returns to his homeland, a small town in the country to see his father, who is a local court judge and with whom he has never had a good relationship. However, he ends up offering to defend him when the elderly judge is charged with murder. The best of the film is the story, a family drama that holds our attention from the beginning because the characters were so well developed psychologically that they end up touching us. Robert Downey Jr. and veteran Robert Duvall give life to son and father, respectively, and both are huge in their performances, being very good how they interact with each other in front of the camera. But neither are sympathetic characters. They are very similar, cranky and a little stern, and because they are very similar, they have difficulty living together. The rest of the cast plays secondary roles but gives good support to these two actors.

Review title: Could have been so much better! 6/10
Review_body: Review: I'm a big fan of Robert Downey Jr. so my expectations for this movie were really high but I found it quite boring. It really didn't have to be over 2 hours long! Anyway, it's about a hot shot lawyer (Downey) who returns home after the death of his mother. When the funeral is over, he attempts to go back home because of his troubled relationship with his father but he ends up returning because his father has a car accident which killed someone. His dad (Duvall), who is the towns judge, is having chemotherapy due to cancer so he's suffering from memory lose and bad moods swings which is why he can't remember if he ran over the man who got killed. When the police see the damage on his car, he becomes the main culprit for the murder so his son helps to defend him in court. The movie seemed to drag after a while because it's mainly based around the relationship between Downey and Duvall. I was hoping for a deep court drama, like a Few Good Men but it's an emotional drama which doesn't really have that much going on. The performances from the actors were great and I love Downeys infectious screen charisma, but the problem is the storyline which is extremely slow and basic. The courtroom scenes weren't that dramatic but Duvall really does show some true emotion, especially when he's being sick in the bathroom. Anyway, it's worth a watch just to see these actors bring true drama to there characters but I personally was hoping for more from the storyline. Watchable!Round-Up: Downey is hot property in Hollywood at the moment and he's loved by audiences and his fellow actors. He has come full circle after his crack addiction problems and he's looking pretty good at the age of 50. Duvall is still pulling out great performances at the age of 84 and it's hard to remember him in the early years in movies like the Godfather and Apocalypse Now. In this film, the chemistry between the 2 characters was great and very realistic. When the scary looking Billy Bob Thornton goes against them in court I honestly thought that there was going to be fireworks but the director didn't take advantage of the opportunity. Maybe that's why it didn't blow up at the box office but at least it made it's money back.Budget: $50million Worldwide Gross: $84millionI recommend this movie to people who are into their deep dramas about a hot shot lawyer who returns home to bury his mum and ends up defending his dad in court after he causes a fatal car accident. 6/10

Review title: A few good scenes with a lot of crap piled on top
Review_body: Two great actors wasted with a crappy script and a terrible director.A lack of attention to details will always ruin a movie and this one has it in spades. I don't believe that using deus ex machina in any movie is valid and I also dislike continuity errors. All of them exist in this movie and it bleeds out because of them.The story is a good one, successful son who never got along with his father comes up because the mom he loved dies. He comes home to deal with the father and other issues, while having to deal with crap back home (via long distance).There is a lot of growth for the characters but there is too much getting in the way of the actors and the script. There is no breathing room for them to fully reach the pinnacle of the story. There is a lackluster ending which is disappointing.

Robert was born for these sexist and self-destructive sexist roles, they fall like gloves, and I have a crush on seeing them go bad and fall out of their own arrogance, here we have a beaten and démodé drama, but as an elegant and modern outfit, which makes it very attractive, and with good doses of friction, discussions, and some emotion...

Review title: A little too long but still very good
Review_body: I like courtroom movies. Each case is always so unique and in an industry that is in desperate need of every scrap of originality it can muster that's a very good thing. In 'The Judge' the court case is really more of a framing devise than what the movie is entirely about, but it's still very interesting. Robert Duvall has always been known as a very fine actor, in fact he's widely considered one of the best in the business. He's been nominated for an Academy Award in a Supporting Role for his performance here and while he has no chance of upsetting J.K Simmons for his role in 'Whiplash' it is still very deserving. It's a gritty performance and he does an amazing job of taking what could easily have been a very unlikeable character and making the audience really feel for him and relate. His scenes with Robert Downey Jr. are very well acted especially and have a tremendous amount of chemistry.The only thing really holding the film back is a lack of memorable scenes. The movie as a whole works very well but it all comes across a bit "by the book" and never offers up anything game changing or uniquely profound. Aside from that and possibly running about 20 minutes longer than it needed to (we probably didn't need to see every step of Downey's journey to Indiana in such length) it really is hard to fault. It's genuinely touching and every character is given a fantastic and unique arc that is never overbearing but always interesting. I can't help but feel it was just one great scene away from receiving a Best Picture nomination.

I am pleased that court activities do not form the main part and idea of the movie, as court dramas tend to be arid and with limited venue and space. Although you see several lawyers and hear a lot of legal vocabulary, the main theme is still the story of a family, its ups and downs, interpretations and misinterpretations... The events are realistic, the characters are solid and well elaborated, and the plots contains multiple twists, paving the way for logical, yet inevitable solution.But the main gem is the cast - strong and even; although Robert Duvall as Judge Joseph Palmer gives the finest performance (and he was 82 years old already when the filming began!), all the others are also well equal to the task: Robert Downey, Jr. as Henry "Hank" Palmer, Vera Farmiga as Samantha "Sam" Powell, Vincent D'Onofrio as Glen Palmer, Billy Bob Thornton as Dwight Dickham - what a bunch of great actors who would shine in every movie, irrespective of the topic or era. Even if you might some scenes are too long or sophisticated for you, just watch the acting, and the movie flows on, while the characters are developing, getting rid of their stereotypes.Accordingly, a pleasant movie to recommend, and hopefully Robert Duvall's Academy Award nomination will process into his triumph.

I saw "The Judge", starring Robert Downey Jr.-the Iron Man movies, Ally McBeal_tv; Robert Duvall-Jack Reacher, Crazy Heart; Vera Farmiga-Bates Motel_tv, The Conjuring and Billy Bob Thornton-Fargo_tv, Bad News Bears_2005.This is a good example of some great actors doing what they are trained to do, act. There are no car chases, explosions, etc.-Not that there is anything wrong with those enhancements to movies-But sometimes, it's just nice to see a movie like this one. Downey plays a successful big city lawyer that mostly defends criminals, and gets them released. His mother passes away and he returns to his small Indiana hometown for the funeral. Duvall plays his father, a judge, but they do not get along. They both have issues with each other. Before Downey leaves, Duvall is linked to the murder of a man that he once had in his courtroom so Downey decides to stay and try to keep his father out of jail. Billy plays the opposing attorney and Vera plays an old girlfriend of Downey's that still lives in the small town. Although the movie does have a few courtroom scenes, the focus is on the relationship between father and son. It's rated "R" for language and sexual situations-no nudity-and has a running time of 2 hours & 21 minutes. It's not one that I would buy on DVD but it would be a good rental.

Before I provide my final verdict for "The Judge", I must confess that I did not think Director David Dobkin had it in him to direct a serious drama. Dobkin is known for directing such comedies as "Wedding Crashers" and "The Change Up"; while they are fun flicks, they are not exactly challenging to the cerebral cortex."The Judge" is not perfect, it does have some monotonous scenes that should have been sentenced back to the editing room. But nevertheless, Dobkin did hold court pretty moderately in his orchestration of "The Judge". The movie stars Robert Downey Jr. as Chicago hotshot lawyer Hank Palmer. Hank goes back to his small hometown in Indiana for his mother's funeral. Hank's father is the town judge, Joseph Palmer; portrayed by the great Robert Duvall. Hank and Joseph have had a rocky relationship for years. When unexpectedly Joseph is arrested for murder, Hank decides to represent him even though daddy judge objects to that at first. Vincent D'Onorfio plays Hank's family-man brother Glen, and Jeremy Strong plays Hank's youngest brother Dale who has brain damage due to an accident that happened years ago with Hank being behind the wheel. The lovely Vera Farmiga also joins in the jury of supporting acting here portraying Hank's high school sweetheart Samantha. Billy Bob Thornton also makes a showing as the hard-knock prosecuting attorney Dwight Dickham, whose hard edge ways pretty much make him the first syllable of the character's last name. The muscle behind "The Judge" is most definitely the outstanding supporting performance from Robert Duvall, and the solid leading work from Robert Downey Jr. "The Judge" is guilty of a very few filmmaking flaws, but in no way would I object for anyone to view "The Judge", and let you judge it for yourself**** Good

Review title: A good dramatic film that pulls on the heartstrings
Review_body: I have wanted to see the judge for a while now and I have finally seen it and I did like it. The premise of the film sees a hotshot lawyer having to go back home to help represent his father in a court case. Now Robert Downey jnr has been so busy with his work as iron man that we haven't seen him do as much dramatic work. But he is fantastic in this film, he has the charisma that you expect but also nails the true drama in his character and its refreshing to see. Robert duvall plays his father in the film and he is phenomenal in this film. He is a stern character but you feel the true pain in his character and his chemistry with Downey is great. Vincent donofrio plays downeys brother and he was also great in the film and he really sold the drama between him and downey. Billy bob Thornton is the lawyer against Downey and he is really good in the film too even though I felt he was underutilized. The story had some of the best family drama that I have seen in any film for a while and it was the big strength of the film. However, I felt that there were some wasted plot points such as downeys romance and his father daughter troubles. The script had some fantastic dramatic dialogue that really helped the power scenes. The problem is that the film also tried some humour in the film and none of it worked at all which hurt the film. The style is also a bit of a mixed bag. The dramatic scenes and courtroom scenes were fantastic I just felt like the tone of the film was a bit messy and hurt the film. Overall this is a good film that will pull on your heartstrings.

Review title: Terrence Howard once sang about how hard it is to be a . . .
Review_body: . . . pimp, but Robert Downey, Jr. as "Hank Palmer" shows that it's 10 times harder to be the child of a judge than it is to be IRON MAN. Especially if your "Pepper Potts" is sleeping with the brother you disabled, leaving you at risk to "make out" with the niece you don't even know you have, at a time when everyone expects you to be Pop's savior on a first-degree murder rap because your parents are named "Mary" and "Joseph." This gem of a movie has enough dirt to keep an old-time soap opera in business for two or three seasons. It will tug at the heartstrings of anyone who's ever been a child or a parent, and may be almost too much to witness for those of us who've been both. Episodes of simultaneous vomiting and diarrhea always are hard to stomach, but THE JUDGE tastefully withholds this scene until after most of the audience can be expected to have munched through their concessions purchases. If you need a cotton candy brain to fully appreciate Downey's outings as IRON MAN, a cast iron stomach should see you through his work in THE JUDGE.

Review title: Enjoyable when it centers on the family dynamics, but fails as a courthouse thriller
Review_body: "My father is a lot of unpleasant things, but murderer is not one of them."The Judge may not be the highly effective powerhouse courtroom drama we were expecting when we first heard about the pairing of Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall, but it isn't the terrible film some critics are describing it as either. Most of us had high expectations for The Judge but once the first reviews started coming in my expectations were lowered so I went into this with moderate expectations. It is a somewhat effective melodrama when it centers on the father and son family dynamics, but when it tries to include other subplots like the courtroom drama scenes and the relationship with a former lover, the film falls flat and feels overlong. Director David Dobbin succeeds when he gets Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall in a room together. Those are the most effective scenes of the film and they standout because both actors are on the top of their game. Dobbin however fails when he tries to cram other dramatic elements into this film, and he does so way too often. At 144 minutes, The Judge could have been more effective if it were cut short and centered exclusively on the family dynamics rather than on the rest of the subplots that Dobbin is cramming into the film. The problem is that Dobbin is trying too hard to make a serious film since this is his first time directing a non-comedy. Audiences who were expecting a Grisham style courtroom drama will be disappointed because that aspect of the story falls flat, but as a film centering on a dysfunctional father and son relationship it succeeds thanks to the two lead actors. When the two Roberts get together The Judge pulls at your heart strings effectively, but the rest of the scenes do feel clichéd and manipulative (especially the scenes involving those home movie projections). I also enjoyed this as a character study of the different family dynamics and I appreciated the films intentions about giving an honest portrayal of aging through Duvall's character. There are some powerful scenes, but they are ruined sometimes by the clichés the film follows.Aside from Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall's powerful performances (they are both at their best here), there is also a very interesting supporting performances from Vincent D'Onofrio. His scenes with Downey are relevant as well and he holds his own. Billy Bob Thornton doesn't really get much character development considering the court case is simply included as an excuse to keep this family together. Farming is a wonderful actress and she gives a strong performance as well, but her scenes really don't add anything to the film and their subplot could have been left out. The premise of the film isn't anything we haven't seen before either. The story centers on a hot shot lawyer from a big city who is returning to the small town he grew up and ran away from, for his mother's funeral. He doesn't want to stay long because his relationship with his father is a disaster and we get a glimpse of it early on. Those scenes are powerful but not entirely original. Downey plays the smart mouth witty son to perfection, while Duvall is the uptight and stern father who he can easily play in his sleep. The only moment where Duvall and Downey were on screen together that didn't work for me was when they begin discussing their personal issues while his father stands on trial. That was just one example of a forced moment where melodrama seemed more important than authenticity. There are several moments like this that hurt this film, but the few authentic moments are powerful enough to recommend this it. The Judge isn't a bad film, it's just one that had the potential to be so much more.

(Flash Review)First off, the acting was good. Probably the highlight, even though Duvall and Downey Jr. stick within their expected roles. If only the story wasn't so template and didn't telegraph plot-points. Downey Jr. plays the big city, fast-talking lawyer with the quick wit and Duvall, his father, the small-town judge with squeaky clean morals. Son comes back home for mother's funeral and as the story unfolds around father's recent car accident, who big city lawyer son ends up defending him, their relationship and buried emotions begin to surface. Good acting around the overly-dramatic scenes, typically unrealistic courtroom scenes as well as the stereotypical divorced, single and attractive woman to mix it up with Downey Jr. It was a fine movie, something to pass the time and enjoy but certainly nothing to ponder for later.

Review title: Guilty of clichés, but still comes out a winner
Review_body: Clichés abound, but a few strong moments and a powerhouse cast lift it to another level. In particular there's a scene with Robert Duvall--and if you've seen the movie you know which one I'm talking about, and if you haven't I won't spoil it here--that's one of the bravest pieces of acting I've ever seen in a film. Ego and vanity, the armor and shield of your typical "movie star", are set aside, leaving him utterly and completely vulnerable. Dude's just playing chess while the rest of us play checkers.At times the movie's focus wanders, and at nearly 2 1/2 hours it's far too bloated, but there's more than enough here to make 'The Judge' worthwhile.
Compelling story but just didn't do it for me. Never really felt sorry for the over privileged characters.

Initially, I did not think much of Robert Downey as an actor; I thought he was just another hip, pretty face, of which there were plenty in Hollywood. But as time passed, he made a greater and greater impression on me as a fine actor; especially in Chaplin, for which I thought he deserved the Academy Award. Since then, he has maintained a very high level of performance. This film features a strong all-star cast including a nice, understated performance by Billy Bob Thornton, and another fine performance from veteran, Robert Duval. Vincent Donofrio is always very good as well, but it appears he has been packing away those doughnuts he used to try and hide in Full Metal Jacket. The distaff members perform admirably, but this is mostly an actor's film. The script is tight and the production values are first-rate. Highly recommended.

Review title: If you want to watch a good courtroom film then watch 12 Angry Men
Review_body: Only courtroom stuff was good other than that it is full of cliches and boring side story. Actors saved it for me.

Robert Downey has given us good acting plenty of times. He gave "Ironman" his sarcastic soul. He found the desperation in the teens of "Less Than Zero", the sadness inside "Chaplin" and we can go through at least half of his films and find that they work because he's truly a remarkable character actor. Who would have thought he needed something a little conventional to shine? Maybe it was because this is the kind of genre that has been cheapened for a while as we are treated to a hybrid that combines the slasher film/mystery with a touch of legal seasoning.This film's heart is the law and its effects on the lives of those who believe in it. "The Judge" is the story of two people, their relationship, and how it grows from something pure to something that has decayed over the years, poisoning whatever love and beauty it had before. It has some contrived moments, but they never overpower the basic story like like the gimmicks of the recent "This is Where I Leave" which succumbs to overacting and vulgarity. It has more in common with Grisham's thrillers, without the intrigue. "The Judge" has a more personal focus, and it works out beautifully.Downey plays a successful and ruthless attorney who specializes in defending the guilty. He will work for those who can afford his services and couldn't care less whether they are innocent or not. It is as if he thrives on showing how good he is at thrashing the opposition, bragging how good he is at what he does, and he's never happy because the one compliment he wants is not to be gained so easily.One day he's forced to return to his hometown and face the demons in his past, particularly that father he seems to hate. He only refers to him as "The Judge", and Duvall is icily effective in the way he approaches his sons. He seems to have only love for his recently deceased wife, so we know he has a heart, but why is he so distant and hard on his sons?As the story unfolds, we find out why the father/son relationship is so strained. It's got roots on a couple of tragic development which force both father and soon to react out of disappointment which ironically originates in misunderstanding what is best for each other. Downey quickly begins to get closer to his father, and we see how these two had the stronger st bond in the family, and they get closer as it becomes obvious that time is of the essence here.Enters the legal drama, and Downey has to defend his father in a jury trial to prove his innocence. Things are not easy because the truth might never be revealed. "The Judge" is after all now sitting in the accused's chair, and his testimony is affected by circumstances that prove to be key to the eventual resolution of the case.Throughout the film, Downey does nothing short of spectacular while he is acting. His range has never been more effectively displayed. There is anger, love, happiness, sadness, misery, disappointment, resolve, determination, shock, and just about everything we have seen in great character performances. I couldn't help thinking about Vivien Leigh's work in "Gone With the Wind", as she evolves from the spirited teen into a mature woman who fails to realize the truth until it's too late. I was looking at an actor joining the likes of Streep's magnificent turns, Bale's intense embodiment of a character, leaving nothing untouched, with no hesitation to show the raw sentiments that torture him.This might be his performance that puts him on the company of Day Lewis' "Lincoln", Leigh's "Blanche", Peck's "Atticus", Streep's "Sophie", and some of those iconic roles and performances. In the end we see him contemplating his future by looking at one of this father's office objects, and we realize that we have gone full circle, and that he's about to become what he always feared but he really wanted.

"The law is the only thing capable of making people equal" Hank Palmer(Robert Downey Jr.) is a shrewd and successful lawyer with a smooth tongue. A chatterbox that overwhelms you with its arguments and you can't get in a word edge-ways. He uses arguments and counter-arguments in such a natural way, as if he's ordering something to eat at a sandwich bar. Therefore for some he's an insufferable person who does not mince his words. My favorite scene is the confrontation with some drunk local figures in a local bar where he and his two brothers Glen (Vincent D'Onofrio) and Dale (Jeremy Strong) chat about lost times. The way he gives those windbags tit for tat and knows how to silence them,is a perfect representation of who the person Hank Palmer is. This piece reminded me a bit of Matt Damon in "Good Will Hunting" who puts a group of university students in their place. Slyly I enjoy those moments. I know, schadenfreude is not a nice virtue.Because of family circumstances, Hank must return to his hometown which he turned his back on years ago. The funeral of his mother confronts him with his past. There are his brother Glen, who once stood at the beginning of a promising career as a professional baseball player, and his other mentally handicapped younger brother Dale, who has a passion for filming and usually carries a camera to capture all kinds of scenes. And then there's his father Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) who's invariably called "Judge" by everyone. A bitter man who can look back at an impressive career as a judge in the town of Carlinville and who's more concerned with his legacy as a righteous judge than his current miserable situation. The next day after the three brothers went on a night out, Mark Blackwell is found dead and his blood is found on the grill of Judge's car. Hank's father can't remember anything and pleads not guilty. Were it not, that years ago he made the error to give this Mark Blackwell a light imprisonment who after being released drowned a 16-year-old girl, there probably still would be some doubt. But this fact does give Judge a decisive motive for murder with hit and run."The Judge" is not a typical courtroom drama as we've seen frequently. It's a subtle made family drama with the legal dispute as a side issue and the emphasis on the family joust. Unresolved resentment and mistakes made in the past, played an important role. The whole is explained in detail in a brilliant and subtle way and time has been taken to outline the whole family situation, based on conversations and fragments filmed by Dale. And despite the significant playing time of 140 minutes, you won't get the feeling that you have to drag yourself through it. An intriguing and fascinating family sketch that sometimes tends to become melodramatic (culminating in the confrontation in the basement during a suddenly emerging tornado).It was to be expected that the confrontation between Downey Jr. and Duvall would guarantee some acting from the top shelf. A brilliant performance by Duvall as the stubborn paterfamilias, who nevertheless expresses some human feelings as his granddaughter comes to visit (incidentally also an admirable role played by Emma Tremblay). Downey can be arrogant. He demonstrated this already in "Iron Man". The difference is that this bugged me in "Iron Man", whereas it fits perfectly here. And definitely worth mentioning are the two emotional (and sometimes funny) renditions of D'Onofrio and Strong. Vera Farmiga ("The Conjuring"), as the ex-girlfriend of Hank, we see trotting along and merely serves as a distraction of the clash of arms between the two Palmer-clan members."The Judge" is a pleasure to watch when it comes to the acting, but ultimately it's still just a typical family drama with a court case as a side topic. For the rest, it's crammed with every imaginable emotive subject such as death, illness and an unwavering feud. The priority is the father-son relationship with some story-lines wrapped around it. Ultimately these stories have nothing to do with the core of the matter and only serve to incorporate frequent used clichés so it's guaranteed you'll use a handkerchief to wipe away a tear.More reviews here : http://opinion-as-a-moviefreak.blogspot.be

Review title: Father's Stern Discipline, Finally, Rights Son
Review_body: Exploring his past isn't easy for Hank Palmer, a high-powered Windy City lawyer who has carved his niche defending wealthy criminal types. You could say, "somebody's gotta do it" and you'd be right. What isn't quite right is the life Hank turned to in order to become the crack criminal defense lawyer he is. The Judge is all about personal introspection of roads taken with a tally sheet heavy on loss. The kind of soul searching that can come not entirely by choice, but by fate. Whoever Hank Palmer has become is about to snap into a focus, one he simply didn't set out to ponder. As this is a slice of life story there are quite a few layers soon to be peeled back. Because things like this often begin to unfold due to pivotal events the event here is attending Hank's mothers funeral and the ensuing uneasy reunion with the father he chose to forget.Robert Downey Jr. is one of those amazing actors who can do that ridiculous superhero comic book stuff brilliantly, but give him a tragically tortured soul in a very real,i.e not ridiculous, situations and he rises above all. This role is quite a contrast to the bombast of Tony Stark and even with some of the swagger of Stark hovering this is a much more nuanced presentation. Downey's troubled journey and renaissance in real life, likely, have forged an excellent performance here. Now, this isn't to say this yarn isn't puffed up with all the clichés' such as old girlfriends, confrontations with testosterone and beer enhanced red necksbut, The Judge has it's heart in a place where this is just a little garish color around a much better picture that is slowly painted. Robert Duvall as Judge Palmer is the field from which the fruits of Hank Palmer spring forth. Duvall, the consulate actor he is, delivers the character of Judge Palmer to perfection. Even in anger Judge Palmer never comes off as anything but poignant.This movie delivers with heart and soul. The cast couldn't be better, the cinematography is as beautifully framed as a Normal Rockwell Saturday Evening Post cover. The story itself, well it's never more sensational than real which is to say it works on a very humanistic level. The Judge humbly weaves it's magic by not overreaching and succeeds by just showing a family's triumphs and tragedies that ring true.

Rating: ☆☆ This film is not recommended.There is a scene in The Judge where the two characters, a father and son, walk in different directions from each other. That serves as a heavy-handed metaphor for their stormy relationship (and that's not even counting a real storm later in this film either). That moment sums up this overstuffed film whose many subplots go in all sorts of different directions.The filmmaker, David Dobkin, is addled with a weak screenplay that can't seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be a courtroom drama or a family melodrama about a dysfunctional Midwest clan.The main plot of the film seems to be a) a slick city lawyer named Hank (Robert Downey) returns home to an ailing and distant father, Judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) who b) may have killed a man during a hit and run accident. Those two stories never gel. Add to that, c) a romantic entanglement with a former girl left behind with a past secret, d) an unhappy brother who never amounted to much, d) a low-functioning younger brother who is obsessed with his camera and e) another ambitious lawyer out to win his case against Hank's father. Neither do all this other plot points come together well.What does work is the fine acting by the Roberts. Downey takes on a serious acting role, a nice change of pace from his action hero work, and reminds moviegoers how skillful an actor he can be. Of course, playing opposite an acting legend like Mr. DuVall does up the game. Duvall reprises his Great Santini character as the dominating father figure, but he excels in his quieter scenes as a man coming to terms with his own morality. Although the film cannot stay clear of clichés, their scenes together still resonate with tension.The other actors are left with underdeveloped characters to play. Vincent D'Onofrio, Vera Farmiga, Jeremy Strong, Dax Shepard, and Billy Bob Thornton bring their A game to their film roles.The problem with The Judge is its troublesome screenplay by Nick Schenk and Bill Dubuque that constantly rambles from one subplot to the next and never builds to a satisfying conclusion. The family drama is predictable fare and the courtroom case is fairly predictable also. David Dobkin's direction keeps everything moving but with nowhere to actually go. So what we are left with is a well acted film in search of a better script.I rule that less would have been more in the case of The Judge. GRADE: C+Visit my blog at: www.dearmoviegoer.comANY COMMENTS: Please contact me at: jadepietro@rcn.com

Review title: A good break from seeing Robert Downey Jr. as a superhero
Review_body: Facing a divorce, a great yet not so honest city lawyer Hank goes back to his home town in Indiana to attend his mother's funeral. He meets his father Joseph, an honest judge of the town who have always been an opposition to his ways and opinions. After leaving with anger over an argument about the divorce, Hank returns again as his brother tells him his father is charged with manslaughter with his car. The victim is a Mark Blackwell whom Joseph tried once. Hank easily sets his father out of interrogation but further investigation really makes Joseph a suspect. For the preliminary hearing, Joseph chooses his lawyer, an honest but seemingly incompetent man to defend him, whom Hank repeatedly harass over which. The case goes on to trial and the lawyer stepped down admitting his lack of experience. Being formal, Hank offers his father a 'contract' on Hank being his counsel. Yet there are still instances where Joseph insists on using honest ways, contradicting Hank's cunning ways of the loopholes. Hank's own investigations find that Joseph is undergoing a medication that can cause some degree of memory loss. Hank's daughter comes from Chicago for a weekend. Contrary to Hank's thoughts, she relates smoothly with Joseph. When she goes back home, Hank gets hints that her manners look like his ex-girlfriend's daughter Carla, thus he suspects that Carla is his kid. Things go on at the trial. Hank manages to prove that it's hard to see the road of the crime scene, but the prosecutor work on Joseph's pride making him convince his feelings that though he can't remember hitting him, he's glad that the victim's dead. Hank pulls out his last trick, bringing out the medication and memory loss. This angered Joseph and he requests to change counsels. But the presiding judge demands Joseph to complete his testimony first with Hank. Asked why did Joseph gave a lenient sentence to Blackwell all those years ago, Joseph reveals the truth that he saw Hank in Blackwell and Blackwell in Mark interchangeably. This grew his mercy to give Blackwell a new chance, and grew his strictness to Hank so that Hank doesn't grow to be like Blackwell. The jury verdicts Joseph as not guilty of murder but guilty of manslaughter, and the presiding judge sentences him to four years in prison. Joseph gets out on parole seven months later and Hank picks him up. They go fishing on a lake and Joseph admit Hank's talent as a lawyer and dies there.The story overall is interesting enough. It combines many diverse drama subjects in one movie; from father-son relationship, childhood nostalgia, cunning lawyer job, and a 'nursing home' story element. Being billed as only a drama genre, the law case is nicely presented as mysterious at the beginning. Also the comedic inserts are also nice.One thing I don't really get though is that those many things have some great deal of focus that the whole movie doesn't really have one main focus. The title says to focus on the law case, but the presence of Samantha's and Lauren's points of the story kind of pulls back the focus from the case and stretches the drama into a big span. This is also not yet mentioning the potential story at Dickham's side.I like how the story depicts Hank's character. Being as hard as his dad Joseph, he again and again abandons him yet again and again returns to his side even swallowing in the rejections from Joseph. Unfortunately this adequate character building doesn't cover the rest of the characters presented. The movie only presents one or two traits for any other character and strangely keeps focusing on those traits. It makes the other characters look like robots or something.The acting parts is a good overall for me. The two Roberts nicely put down their acting on those heated arguments and father-son moments. Downey Jr. still retains his fast talking skill nicely. Except for those father-son moments, he still really looks like a Tony Stark or Sherlock Holmes in character to me, though. Robert Duvall very nicely portrays the old stubborn geezer who once was someone. Dax Shepard nicely adds to the comedic aspect. The other cast members make the story more alive well enough.For me, The Judge (2014) deserves a 6 out of 10 score. It's quite a nice entertainment, a drama with added mystery and comedic aspects. If only story has more stable and narrowed down focus, I think it can be better. One thing for sure though, It's a good break from seeing Robert Downey Jr. as a superhero.

Review title: Despite A Reasonably High Rating, The Judge is Still Underrated.
Review_body: The Judge stars Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall. Need I say more? The extraordinary gifted and talented Roberts lead an all-star cast that includes Billy Bob Thornton, Vera Farmiga, and Vincent D'Onofrio, and Dax Shepard. I will agree with most haters that the courtroom portion is a bit weak and and Downey Jr is too Tony Starky, but who cares? I would honestly say the only flaw is that it is too long. This could easily have been less than two hours.Downey Jr plays hotshot lawyer from Chicago named Hank Palmer who returns to his suburban Indiana hometown for his mother's funeral and must contend with the town and family he left years ago. I like this early portion because it shows very beautiful shots of the sun beating down on nature and rivers that make it very nice to see. We also get a good look at who these characters are. Downey Jr's comeback role of Tony Stark has made him star as all-too similar characters since Iron Man's release, so his role as Hank Palmer does lots of wisecracks. His father, Judge Joseph (Duvall) as been accused of murdering a young man he hates and Hank jumps to represent him. Hank bears a slim chance of his father being let off due to apparent evidence and telltale signs. Hank and Joseph rebuild their lives together and rekindle their relationship as father and son. Joseph's physical and mental health is deteriorating and it is sad to see what is happening with him. I wouldn't call it melodrama, just great acting. When it gets to the courtroom portion, yeah it's not complex or as good as To Kill A Mockingbird or 12 Angry Men, but who cares? The plot and characters have been firmly established and deeply examined to make the court part great. Take the courtroom part by itself and it's weak, but you can't have one without the other. The courtroom portion is not to be informative about the law or to centre the movie on, it is there to help our two stars grow and be closer than they've ever been.This is the perfect father-son movie to watch. Downey Jr and Duvall are captivating in this wonderful film.3.5/4

Review title: VIEWS ON FILM review of The Judge
Review_body: Taking place in Southern Indiana (you can tell because the landscape is full of foothills) and directed by a guy who is known chiefly for making comedies, The Judge is a long yet briskly paced courtroom drama. The overall plot concerns a hot shot Chicago lawyer who must defend his own father (a longtime judge presiding in a small town via the Hoosier state) against a stone cold murder charge. This mean-spirited, resentful (you could throw in spiteful too) lawyer flies into town initially to go to his mother's funeral. He ends up staying longer than needed when his father's dim-witted counsel can't handle the intensity of the case, a case involving a death by hit-and-run. Robert Downey Jr. plays the big city attorney (Henry "Hank" Palmer) while the legendary Robert Duvall plays his tough as nails, not to mention bullheaded judge father (Joseph Palmer).As an originally conceived film with a title that averts to something John Grisham would approve of, The Judge didn't really remind me of any other dramas except for its mild sentiment towards certain clichés. You know, the aspects of a rich, well-off lad who comes back to his small hometown after he abandons his family and leaves behind the high school sweetheart that he once loved. And oh yeah, you can also throw in the cranky old timer who wasn't a good father and may or may not be a recovering alcoholic (a la 1982's The Verdict). No matter though. In essence, this is an absorbing, chaotic, messy, yet powerfully realized downer of a movie. It's depressing in its dysfunctional family dynamic and its ending is clearly anti-Hollywood (really not what you'd except). However, there is never a dull moment and at roughly two hours and twenty plus minutes, there's a lot of movie in this movie. You get what you paid for and then some.The acting is top drawer, all down the line. Downey Jr. and Duvall have only been in the same flick one other time (1998's The Gingerbread Man) and clearly don't look related. But they work well together. Their performances in the lead roles hit you like a ton of bricks. Watching them spar in scene after gut wrenching scene, you feel as if they were actually bear and cub in real life. It's truly intense. And I gotta admit, Robert Downey Jr.'s "Hank" was tough to put up with for the majority of the running time. There's a lot of pent up anger there. There's also lots of moodiness, regret, and narcissism going on. Downey Jr. with his fast talking mannerisms and blatant Tony Starkness (you know, his character from Iron Man), looks like he's going to a bad place with this character. You feel like he could just explode at any minute. His performance is no doubt brilliant but gee-whiz, he could have possibly lightened up a bit. As for the rest of cast, they are solid especially Billy Bob Thornton exuding a sort of menacing cool. He plays the prosecutor in Duvall's character's case who is bent on justice (and the prospect of issuing a murder one charge to boot). Finally, we have Vera Farmiga effectively channeling the token, long lost love interest and Vincent D'Onofrio riffing off his The Break Up role by playing "Hank's" otherwise nervous older brother (Glen Palmer). Oh and by the way, did I mention the hard R language these characters carry off with totally relentless aplomb? This ain't no People's Court. This is indeed 12 Angry Men (and you can maybe count some woman too).In conclusion, The Judge is pretty meaty entertainment despite a few hiccups along the way. I mean I could have done without a couple of scenes involving projectile vomiting and the sight of runny poop coming out of an 80 plus year old man (note to director David Dobkin: you're not making The Change-Up here. You're making a full-fledged, human drama). Also, I couldn't figure out why Downey Jr.'s "Hank" stayed at his father's storage room (at the Harper family home) during the opening funeral. I mean initially they hated each other, right? So I'm thinking that "Hank" could have at least found a hotel room (even in the small, fictitious hick town of Carlinville, Indiana). Regardless, this early fall release gets a recommendation from me. If you decide to take in a viewing, remind yourself that this film is not just a farce about the fate of a dying man through a handful of jurors. Think of what's on screen as a rekindling of fathers and sons by which the characters have extremely strong personalities and for the most part, are just too bad for each other. My final verdict on The Judge: Guilty, as in you're guilty if you don't check it out at a theater near you.

Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr) a lawyer and estranged son of Judge Joe Palmer (Robert Duvall) defends his father accused of a hit and run accident that resulted in a death. The movie should have been titled The Son because it is mostly about Hank Palmer and his wayward ways growing up in the Joe Palmer household. Hank's mother has just died and now Hank must deal with his set-in-his-ways father. We hear all the non-compassionate and brash ways the young Hank treated everyone as he climbed the ladder to success. The family is dysfunctional in many ways, but other issues crop up to complicate matters. These back stories about the family are fine, but we kept looking for an edge that would prove The Judge not guilty of the charges. So we kept watch with every conversation that Hank has with friends and family to see if something they said would cast some light into getting a not guilty verdict. At the same time we kept hoping for a bonding between father and son although we knew this was next to impossible. There should have been more tension between father and son and even in the courtroom. I didn't feel that tension. Maybe you will. I kept hoping for a bonding and something that would help the Judge. There should have been tons of tension, and I didn't feel any. I guess, to be honest, I didn't care for either the son or the father the way I should have. Maybe. I just felt something wasn't right (could it have been the dialogues?) Hmmm..No Oscars as the acting all around was good, not great. Supporting cast members: Billy Bob Thornton as the opposing lawyer, Dwight Dickham; Vera Farmiga as Samantha (Hank's high school love); Ken Howard as the Judge in Joe's trial; Vincent D'Onofrio as Glen (Hank's older brother); and Jeremy Strong as Dale (Hank's younger brother) were all very good.To be honest Billy Bob's character as opposing counsel Dwight Dickham was so good I wanted to give him an Oscar. He is that good. He out-shined both Downey Jr and Duvall.I really liked that silver metallic ring that opened up into a drinking glass for Billy Bob Thornton's character Dickham as he displayed it on the table in the courtroom. Hey, I need to get me one of those. The ending was kind of inconclusive and you will have to read into it what you want. I mean there were many threads that started in the beginning and they never came full circle to resolution. So you may have to come up with them yourself. They in themselves are not important, but they were there. I'm just saying. (7/10)Violence: No. Sex: No. Nudity: No. Language: Yes, some not all that much.

Movies like The Judge live on a different planet. You only find the dilemmas, dynamics and inner conflicts in saccharine movies like this. It stems from lazy writing, or at least, very unimaginative writing. Its concept is a very do or die one, and it falls flat on its face. It wants us to support a murderer as if what he did was right. This lifetime movie views of morality. There's blasé incest thrown in for good measure. None of The Judge's content sat right with me, it's not offensive, just poor. It reaches to the bottom of textbook clichés and refuses to develop anything, leaving the actors on their own, but it isn't enough for them to chew on. It has a loose theme of legacy that struggles to resonate. Robert Downey Jr. tries his best to impress Robert Duvall and while it's a little appropriate for the character, it comes off as inconsistent characterisation. Duvall phones it in besides a few scenes of shouting. A filler nomination would be a nomination too many. Being way overlong doesn't help.4/10

The Judge looks visually terrific and certainly has a couple of very good dramatic scenes, but has a script that ends up borrowing from too many other mellow-dramas and soaps. The overall story is initially interesting (if a bit familiar). IE: How many HBO/TV type miniseries have we all seen peopled by characters living flamboyant messed up lives - where every turn of a page, or new character that emerges from the shadows, and each opening of a door releases yet another closeted skeleton?. It all begins to feel like normality could never have existed in its idyllically set country town. The audience is manipulated like paper under the silhouette artists scissors. Technically slick, with complex editing to bamboozle the viewer into not thinking too much about some of the more icky situations.Performances run the gamut, ranging from flamboyant showy turns to reasonably powerful. Talented Robert Downey Jr. in this case, is investing his own money to tell the industry he's back and out of rehab (lets hope he's matured enough to stay out). Then there's Robert Duvall doing what he's now become known for as doing best. It's just a pity the characters are all so nasty or flawed that it's difficult to feel much empathy for them. As for the more interesting characters (and performances) the honors could well lean towards Emmy nominated Vincent D'Onofrio (who was quite unforgettable in his 80sec turn as Orson Wells in Ed Wood)- here he plays Downy's brother Glen. There's also Oscar nominee Billy Bob Thornton as the sophisticated prosecuting attorney (bringing with him yet another mysterious secret). Thomas Newman's music also adds a nice touch. There's enough happening to keep you watching to the end, but just how deeply it may affect you depends on how much leeway you're prepared to give. Note: If needless bad language puts you off keep the ear wax handy.

Review title: Flawed, but mesmerizing and surprisingly touching drama with strong performances
Review_body: Many probably know Robert Downey Jr. for playing the iconic British detective Sherlock Holmes or suiting up as Iron Man in some of Marvel's most beloved film franchises. This time around however, Downey takes on a more dramatic role in this courtroom drama. He plays Hank Palmer, an ambitious defense attorney in Chicago, who returns to his hometown in Indiana when he learns of his mother's death. There he reconnects is with his estranged brothers Glen (played by Vincent D'Onofrio) and Dale (played by Jeremy Strong), but struggles trying to reconcile his relationship with his disgruntled father Joseph Palmer (played by Robert Duvall), the town's judge. When Joseph becomes a prime suspect of a run-and-hit homicide, Hank takes on the role as his defense attorney in court.This movie may not live up to the best it's potential, but I was quite surprised how riveting it was. Robert Downey Jr. put on a great performance as the main character, but it wasn't quite impressive as Robert Duvall's performance as the main character's father who loses his wife, becomes mean-spirited and descends into alcohol addiction. It's no surprise that his performance landed him an Oscar nomination. The story was great, but maybe not as good as the performances. The film tackles serious topics like divorce and dysfunctional relationships. Robert Downey Jr's character and his are going through a divorce and are in battle for custody of their daughter. His character is also estranged by his father and as the film progresses, tensions grow between the two and becomes a major subplot.The film does great as a drama, but as a courtroom drama, I have to say it is a bit weak. There are many times where the film tries to be emotionally manipulative, especially with Thomas Newman's music score. As a result, it makes the subplot with Hank and his father stand out more to the main storyline. At the same time, it also makes the story very touching and mesmerizing. Towards the end, it gets to the point where it grabs at your heart strings and may make you tear up a little bit, I got close to shedding tears. Basically, the emotional atmosphere had both a positive and negative effect on the story.Overall, The Judge is a decent film. Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall were amazing in this. Yeah, the film may seem a bit overly sentimental and clichéd at times, but I was satisfied with it. As a courtroom drama however, I think it could use some improvements.

Review title: Clichéd, overly-sentimental and waaaay too long.
Review_body: With its noble intentions and heartfelt effort, it's difficult to be critical of this family relationship drama. Focussing on a stubborn old Judge (Robert Duvall) who is alleged to have killed an ex-convict in a hit and run, and his estranged lawyer son (Robert Downey Jr) who is defending him in a small-town court, all the while trying to reconcile their broken relationship, I wanted to be swept up in it. But for all of the love and hard work poured into this motion picture from the director and his cast, The Judge just has too many drawbacks to look past. The score is manipulative rather than affecting, the cinematography is weirdly ostentatious when it should be subtle and the almost two and a half hour runtime is ludicrously unnecessary. Yet the major issues begin and end with the script. Mawkishly sentimental, over-burdened with clichés it can't transcend and dishing out more clunky dialogue than the high-calibre actors deserve, Nick Schenk and Bill Dubuque's screenplay is not up to scratch for what should've been an Oscar contender. Take nothing away from the cast though, Robert Downey Jr nails his key dramatic scenes (although he relies on his trademark cocky charisma a tad too much in the opening 30 minutes), Robert Duvall is fearless in his portrayal of an aging man losing his faculties, and Vincent D'Onofrio demonstrates why he should be getting more big screen supporting work, with a nuanced take on Downey Jr's older brother who never got to leave town for bigger and better things. Unfortunately Vera Farmiga and Billy Bob Thornton – as old flame and slick prosecutor respectively – are inexcusably underused. A massive disappointment for a rare mainstream straight-up drama, the pedestrian screenplay ultimately derails proceedings.

Review title: Too Long and Too Many (bad) Story lines
Review_body: This review is loaded with spoilers. Don't read it unless you have already seen the movie although I strongly suggest that you not watch the movie so there's a bit of a Catch 22 situation here.The recent film The Judge illustrates how bad movies are even when they are trying desperately to be good. They loaded this movie with top talent in the form of Robert Duval and Robert Downey but then they just didn't seem to know when to stop and stacked Hallmark movie of the week clichés until the thing just collapsed under its own weight like the Twin Towers. You could have played cliché bingo and certainly when it is revealed that his high school sweetheart fathered his brother's kid it was time to call a winner.There were so many unbelievable things in the movie. Why did he fly to Indiana if he lives in Chicago? Where would he fly to? His daughter had never seen her grandfather? I can think of anything so horrible that grandpa could have done to deserve being denied access to his granddaughter unless Duvall was diddling young Robert Downey. Had they left out about three of the story lines, one of the brothers, and an hour of film the movie wouldn't have been half bad.There were a couple of good scenes and Downey is completely charming as an actor and one of the very few movie stars I can actually watch.

Review title: legal drama with a solid cast
Review_body: "The Judge" has a backdrop of both courtroom and family tension, it's an emotional drama with brilliant performances (the 2 lead actors standing out) though stuffed with clichés. Robert Downey Junior uses his usual charm and gives a strongly emotional performance. He brings a lot of his own personal experiences into the game and proves he's in the saving grace . Robert Duvall hasn't been this believable for many years, bringing back us some of the power that made him a legend. Its a rare gift that only actors of his caliber do have. Both men are the best part of this film, a film which is not much above an average story, to be honest.

Review title: Robert Downey Jr will win your heart with award-wining performance
Review_body: Robert Downey Jr has carved out an image of himself as smart, quick- witty, one-liner actor who makes an any film worth watching with his impeccable talent. The Judge was close to being a beautiful film with fewer moments to grab your attention.A city lawyer, Hank, returns to his hometown when he learns about his mother's death. He soon realizes his father, who was the judge of the town, is suspected of a murder. Hank takes up the case and investigates the truth behind it.Director of hilarious comedies like Wedding Crashers, Fred Claus and Shanghai Knights, David Dobkin takes up different step to move toward a drama depicting the strong bond between a father and son. The film contains some good humor making the serious drama on the lighter side. However, the second half goes into for a topsy-turvy. The focus shifts from court-room drama to Hank's other relations and breaks the momentum of the film. The editing could have been trimmed by few moment to gain more impact. Despite these short-comings, the screenplay is strong keeping you engaged with soothing background score. Art direction is nice with ecstatic cinematography. Robert Downey Jr will win your heart with award-wining performance. He gets into character of Hank Palmer as if it has been tailor-made for him. He is expressive and will leave you spellbinding with stupendous performance. Robert Duvall was enthralling as usual. The legendary actor lends in a good support and was equally competent.Overall, treat yourself with The Judge. It has good story, class acting and beautiful music. Good 3/5

Review title: Good drama, but a bit of a drag
Review_body: 'The Judge' is a decent enough drama with some very strong acting performances and an interesting plot, but it doesn't do enough to justify the two and a half hour running time. The films goes through lulls where there just isn't enough going on to keep your attention. It seems strange to me that they didn't cut down the scenes of extensive dialogue. A lot of it wasn't really necessary and would have shaved off a good portion of the running time. As it is, the film is too long. The plot doesn't have the depth needed for a two and a half hour film, and whilst the drama and story was nicely done, I would have liked some more intense courtroom scenes. After all, the film centers around 'The Judge'.

Well I certainly understand why this movie was not nominated for 'Best Picture.' The writing was excellent; the casting and acting superb; the production and direction – both flawless, and the storyline, brilliantly logical, fathomable and palpable. Additionally, this movie is insultingly coherent to the masses vice being 'so very special' that some elitist caste of the falsely erudite are sole arbiters of the decipherment of hidden meanings – 'how dare they make a good movie - LUVY?' Another reason this production did not swim in the Oscar Pond is an apparent disdain by 'Hollyweirdos' and their lapdog critics toward 'Robert Duvall.' How insulting are those rare entertainers who come equipped with a spine and refuse to chant the Pavlovian locution of the smarmy and mindless. Mr. Downey beware – minus your suits of armor, CGI and starky attitude; you have proved to be a rarity. This movie reaffirms you as one of the best actors out there, resulting in you being a superior talent. Meh! This movie is a very moving portrayal of a troubled family, coming full circle and finally resolving painful issues in the only possible way. Now I must back-peddle a bit and apologize for lumping all 'critics' together...that is rude of me. They are not all the same. Obviously there are many pundits, distant from Tinsel Town influences who write honestly and frankly. I can deal with those who speak from the heart, and are critical of things I like. But it sure seems like there are those 'bots' out there who tend to copy from others – blindly following the pack if you will. For those of you who veer from the head-nodder sycophants, I salute your independence. Granted, this movie may not be the timeless masterpiece of 'To Kill a Mockingbird', I do consider this to be very high quality entertainment. Rarely can I go to a cinema and not feel like I was just shellacked out of too much money by some young scripter's duplicity or a director's experimental camera work. With 'The Judge' you get what you pay for. No misleading advertisement, just a really great story. I am saddened that this flick did not receive more nominations, but what do I know? I do know I would really like to see more movies like this. Highlighting the superb mechanics that brought this work to light clearly screeches near perfection, vice chirping fail. Great Job.

Review title: Good acting, but too long and too much manufactured family angst.
Review_body: They had it right in terms of casting, anyway. Everyone here seems perfectly cast, even Thornton, who is under-utilized. The performances are rich, and powerful enough to carry this soap opera quite a ways, but ultimately not far enough. Robert Downey Jr. plays a stereotypical hotshot defense attorney who is forced to try to reconcile with his estranged father when dear old dad is accused of manslaughter. Downey's father, played by an increasingly geriatric Robert Duvall, is a no-nonsense small town judge who may or may not have intentionally run down and killed a man with whom he has a troubled history. Did dad do it? And if so, was it intentional? Hard to know, when the old timer's memory is slipping on top of everything else.The trial takes up a good deal of screen time, and this is a good and bad thing. The good thing is it gives us a furlough from the back and forth family angst between Downey, his father, his brothers, his wife, his ex-girlfriend... you name it. Downey has a lot of issues to work out with a lot of people. The tone of this film is relatively serious, and it definitely attempts to tug at your heart strings. Somehow, a lot of this aspect of the film just seems too forced. How many people in real life are so obstinate that they don't speak to their parents for twenty years? Or their brothers? It just isn't believable. Their constant arguments make a long movie seem longer. The bad thing about the trial is that it winds up being pretty anticlimactic. The verdict is predictable, any anyone hoping for a revelation that will exonerate the old timer will be disappointed. Maybe having things all cleared up by an unexpected technicality such as seen in My Cousin Vinny would have made things worse, though. Overall, it just seems like the trial should have had more of a payoff. The film also loses points for a subplot involving Downey possibly making out with a girl who is actually a daughter he never knew about. Logically, it seems like she could be none other than his, but the movie seems to chicken out in that respect. The actual revelation of her father's true identity is pretty hard to believe. There are some good points here, too. Besides the strong acting and casting, the film also makes no bones about the horrors of the advanced stages of cancer. Duvall may never get the chance to put so much of himself into a role ever again. He earned his nomination. Vera Farmiga is also a welcome sight in just about any role. The verdict.... they should have gone for more of a comedic angle. Downey, Duvall,... all of these people could have made it more enjoyable if they just relaxed the film's tone a bit. I don't think Terms of Endearment had so much angst! Watch if you must. 6 of 10 stars. The Hound.

Here's another father son relationship movie. The father just happens to be a judge and the son trying to break out of his "Ironman" rut. There is no Gwyneth Pattrow instead there's Vera Farmiga with a fake looking tattoo.The movie is too long. The director never seemed to yell cut fast enough. Much of the back story was introduced through 8mm home movies. The not so sharp brother was still shooting film in 2014 It isn't going to happen. Perhaps the movie would have looked better if it was shot on film. The digital projection at the local multiplex made things too blue. The color was off on the product placement coke can unless it was a purple Cherry Coke.Good performances can't save this over sappy family drama. No need to see it in a theater it will play OK on a format coming to you soon.

The Judge is the story of Hank Palmer(Robert Downey Jr.) & his family. Hank is a successful lawyer. After a terrible tragedy occurs in the family, he has to return to his home town. Here, he reunites with his family. His father Joseph Palmer(Robert Duvall), is a reputed judge in the town. Joseph Palmer is accused of murder. Now, it is up to Hank to defend his father in court. The Judge is a brilliant movie. Let me make things clear. The Judge is not just a courtroom drama. While the case is happening in the court, Hank reconnects with his brothers & friends in his home town. The Judge is also about a father-son relationship that has undergone a lot of tension over the years. The movie is about how Hank & Joseph try to rebuild that relationship. The courtroom aspect of the film makes it interesting. However, the family aspect of the film makes it emotionally satisfying. Don't get me wrong. There is a substantial amount of comedic scenes in the movie. The highlight of the film is the performances. Robert Downey Jr. is spectacular as Hank Palmer. Although Downey Jr.'s character is kind of the same old sarcastic jerk he always plays, there are many emotional scenes where Downey Jr. shows us the depth of his acting ability. Robert Duvall is outstanding as Joseph Palmer. Duvall has portrayed Joseph's anger & vulnerability, effortlessly. Vera Farmiga is great as Samantha Powell. Billy Bob Thornton is brilliant as Dwight Dickham. Vincent D'Onofrio is incredible as Glen Palmer. Jeremy Strong is incredible as Dale Palmer. Dax Shepherd, Leighton Meester, Ken Howard, Emma Tremblay, Balthazar Getty & David Krumholtz are awesome as C.P. Kennedy, Carla Powell, Judge Warren, Lauren Palmer, Deputy Hansen & Mike Kattan respectively. You cannot miss The Judge. One of the best dramas I've seen in a long time.

Review title: Well-acted, fairly authentic-looking tale that makes you think
Review_body: Is it better to be a big fish in a small pond, or a small(er) fish in a big one? And does the word "better" here mean selfishly better, more lucrative, more likely to ensure full development of talent, or morally more right? And if a person does choose to stay on in a small town, become one of its leading lights, is that not a worthy thing too, but one having the almost-inevitable consequence that the small-town community will eventually bring its one-time idol crashing to the ground? And is that not all the more likely given the sound advice I once received from my own grandfather that: "no matter what you do, some people aren't going to like you". And then, how much more relevant do all of these questions become when the son who moves out to the big city is a litigation lawyer and the father who stayed where he was is a judge who sagely and fairly hears whatever cases come before him? These are the key (but by no means the only) questions dealt with in "The Judge", where the title role goes to Robert Duvall, and that of the wayward son with whom the dad is constantly at loggerheads to Robert Downey Jr. Since these actors give one a fusion of the cinema experiences one goes to a Robert Duvall or Robert Downey film to see, we are (mostly) off to a good start - at least from the point of view of this reviewer. I write "mostly", given that there are a couple of moments of sharper Downey-style "comedy" that do not fit the bill in the context of this film - even glaringly so. The most visible of these concerns his make-out session with a far younger, and very good-looking, woman that leaves our hero wondering later (without excessive guilt or distaste, it must be said) if he has actually been "spending quality time" with his own daughter. But then everything turns out all right, since it's actually only his niece! Well, this IS a small town, and so presumably such stories will indeed raise their ugly heads, but somehow it's rather at odds with the serious main tone of the film, which yields a number of other more-or-less interesting plot lines regarding "old flames", old resentments between brothers (the Downey character has two - nicely and contrastingly played by Vincent D'Onofrio and Jeremy Strong), enmity within a town so cosy that you can't avoid bumping into your sworn enemies as well as your friends, varied memories of a late mother and thoughts about her legacy, terminal disease and yet-several others. Overall, it's a rich enough and real enough tapestry, which only occasionally veers towards cliché - and even then mainly because the kinds of things that happen here really do happen again and again in life. Fathers do feel disappointed with sons, sons do feel held back or left in the shadows by fathers, illness can sometimes change these relationships, brotherly love can be ruined by the stupid behaviour of the moment, and sometimes - just sometimes - a city-slicker can suddenly realise that going back home to a different, ostensibly simpler, life, is actually what he or she most wants to do. Without giving too much more away, it is worth noting the ever-welcome presence of Billy Bob Thornton, whose portrayal of a lawyer dominates some of the courtroom scenes and ensures that we do indeed depart firmly from cliché in this part of the film. So, by the time the final credits on "The Judge" roll the viewer can feel that he/she has experienced the few ups and rather frequent, complex and difficult downs that characterise many a family of people who are not basically "bad", but just find it beyond their capabilities to live the smooth and happy life that mostly seems confined to fairy-tales. For me, that was and is reason enough to watch and enjoy this well-acted film raising and facing up to a plethora of real-life issues.

Review title: Good, but some judicious pruning needed
Review_body: Based on the trailer, my anticipation for seeing "The Judge" was high – – Robert Downey Jnr, Robert Duvall, Vera Farmiga, Billy Bob Thornton great cast. And whilst the film is still good, it suffered in my view from getting rather bogged down in family melodrama.The film opens with a series of stills of various items, all of which play a key part in the plot as it unfurls. Robert Downey Jnr plays hot-shot Chicago defence lawyer Hank Palmer who has a reputation for getting guilty clients off the rap in return for a big fee. He has a hot house, a hot wife and various hot cars. The death of his mother forces him back to his childhood home in Indiana – a place he has not been since his turbulent teenage years. A key reason for his absence is his father Joseph, the Judge of the title (Robert Duvall), with whom he has something of a difficult relationship. When on the day of the funeral Judge Palmer gets into his own brand of legal trouble, a battle ensues as to whether Hank can overturn his father's stubborn views that he is better represented by the local hick lawyer cum shopkeeper C.P. Kennedy (played extremely well by Dax Sheperd).Surrounding this main story are the various sub-plots involving his relationship with his three brothers, his past high school flame and his hauntingly torrid past within his home town.There is great acting on display here. Veteran actor Robert Duvall in particular is exceptional in the lead role, struggling to balance the conflicting demands of his defence with his reputation within the community. Also on top form, Billy Bob Thornton plays a devastatingly fearsome prosecution lawyer – looking like a hawk, you would hate to be in the witness box when he started on you! Robert Downey Jnr, when he gets his teeth into the meatier scenes, is also exceptional: one scene in particular with Thornton in the police station office is just riveting. However, I felt Downey Jnr sometimes drifted into being (as my son neatly put it) "a bit Tony Stark-ish in places": playing out the old disarming comedy schtick works brilliantly in the Iron Man or Sherlock Holmes films, but in this intense drama it sometimes detracted from the character of the film. The ever-reliable, and this time blonde, Vera Farmiga plays Samantha, the high school beauty he left behind who he finds still serving behind the bar of the local diner (although with a nice twist). However her role really isn't fleshed out particularly well and she feels underused in the plot and the film in general.Where the film struggles is in the screenplay which seems to be bogged down with too much 'stuff' that needs to be worked through. The core story, albeit rather formulaic, is good and compelling and doesn't really need all the extra baggage. A more judicious (no pun intended) edit and a reduction in the running time would have helped. The film also seems to try to play a 'fish out of water' card of the hot-shot lawyer in the backwater town, but rather misses the mark. Nice try but no cigar.Another significant criticism for me was in the sound mixing department. This might be my 50+ year old ears, but what with the fast delivery of lines and Duvall's gruff style, a lot of the dialogue didn't successfully make the short journey between ear and brain. And there were some really key lines of dialogue that I missed. If this was on the TV, I would be constantly hitting rewind to catch what was said – unfortunately they don't let you do that in the cinema.Outstanding though was the cinematography (by the great Janusz Kaminski). The film was shot in Massachusetts (principally the town of Shelburne Falls) and it looks beautiful, with clever boom work delivering sweeping and cleverly composed shots of the town. In particular, there is one stunning shot of Downey Jnr driving into town near the start of the film which is just superb. I'm not sure how it was done, but I'm thinking possibly a drone attached to the moving car that was then untethered and flew away? Breathtaking almost worth the ticket price alone! In summary, not a perfect film but one with enough emotion and acting talent on display to be worthy of your multiplex investment.(If you enjoyed this review please sign up for my future reviews at bob-the-movie-man.com. Thanks.)
Sad. Emotional. Gripping. Twists at end. Enthralling from beginning to end.

Review title: Excellent court film! A little bit slow?
Review_body: When I was younger I loved watching movies about courts and judgments and interesting court cases. This film is one of those films. But is even more then that. It is a story about family relationships, about family sickness and passage of time.Robert Duvall had so many great roles in his acting history, this one is powerful one as well. He always delivered, and can be freely called one of the great actors of past few decades.I would recommend that you see this film, if you like family dramas which also include court cases. It is a touching drama and you should take time to see it.

Review title: Quality in every department, and hitting the mark
Review_body: I may be overvaluing The Judge today for I have seen so many half-baked movies lately. I try to pick flicks that get a good rating on IMDb (7+), an ok metascore (60+) and most of the time the result is a lame effort hardly worth an average episode from a good TV-series.Basically The Judge is a winner in all departments. I see some sneer at the basic setup of a made man going back to his childhood little town to confront his past. So what? It is a very fertile starting point if you bring in talent and work. It would not make him justice to say it delivers because this not just a formulaic movie done well, the factored talent give life to a little something extra that changes everything.Such an harmony is the hardest to attain, putting in line all the elements so that nothing feels out of place. Nobody expects to be lucky (?) enough to watch a masterpiece every other day, but most people would be delighted to go more often to the movies if they could expect that high standard of quality.

Review title: Ultimately, the case presented relies on stale precedents we the jury have previously seen in more convincing fashion
Review_body: Does Hollywood do enough to encourage diversity? Robert Downey Jr.'s redemption from troubled drug addict to industry heavyweight overshadows the repetition of his high-energy performance registers. Not that Hollywood would be deeply concerned. This year Forbes ranked him as their Most Powerful Actor and listed tenth on the Celebrity 100 list. Forbes also cited the four Marvel films featuring his character Iron Man earning more than four billion dollars. His success still asks why he cannot diversify his performances and why more couldn't be made of The Judge, which marks a false start for his new production company Team Downey. Downey Jr. is fifty next year, a ripe old age for a superhero, which means he will enter unfamiliar territory by expanding his film choices.
