He and his wife Susan Downey are both producers on The Judge and their power in Hollywood should have enriched the star-studded casting with stronger talent. The cliché riddled script for example was rewritten twice, with the final version penned by Bill Dubuque, a first- time screenwriter. Similarly, the only memorable work by the film's director David Dobkin has been The Wedding Crashers, which is hilarious but hasn't prepared him to make a courtroom drama. The story of The Judge is homogenised from the outset, with the narrative telegraphing the predictable and old fashioned transformation of a big city Chicago lawyer who learns the value of family over money. Hank Palmer (Downey Jr.) is a hotshot lawyer with little time for his young daughter and whose punch line is: "Innocent people can't afford me". After his mother dies, he returns to his Indiana apple-pie hometown to visit his father Joseph (Robert Duvall), an ageing judge who is put on trial for a hit and run case. On the night of the accident, his father might have been back on the drink. Running at 140 minutes, the plot is overstuffed with melodramatic, Sparks-esque problems including: a life-threatening illness, a dysfunctional childhood, a lost love, a potentially estranged daughter, an intimidating lawyer and a family crisis. Not only are there too many elements in the script but they are encapsulated through safe, worn Hollywood staples, like male friendships and retrospective memories, with no new angles of their own. The father and son relationship is contrived because it is shoehorned into the courtroom scenes. Downey must represent his father when the town's nervous lawyer (Parenthood's Dax Shepard) isn't up to the task and as the tension spills into the trial the film's climax ridiculously doubles as a family therapy session.Similar to many mainstream films today, The Judge's adult characters are forced to relieve their childhoods, viewing them ludicrously as the linchpin of the problems in their current lives. While the court case alone could have made a solid 90 minute drama it is interrupted by family scenes infantilising Hank. He has two brothers: Glen (Vincent D'Onofrio), who was set to be a promising baseball player until a car accident injured his hand and Dale (Jeremy Strong), who is slightly challenged but crafty with a video camera. The home movie footage is a cornball excuse to include family footage and show how memories of the past resolve the current day crisis and enhance Hank's parenting skills. Does a person, particularly one well past midlife, become too old to be this sentimental and overly concerned about what happened in their childhood? Another thread further infantilising Hank is when he puts on a Metallica t-shirt and rides a bicycle, which coincides with his reunion with Samantha (Vera Farmiga). She is an old flame, now running a bar, and who has a daughter of her own. A pointless diversion about whether this is also Hank's grown up child, a disastrous thought after he kisses her, would be more suited to a straight comedy vehicle. Ultimately, the case presented relies on stale precedents we the jury have previously seen in more convincing fashion.On paper the cast looks exceptional but turn in serviceable performances. Each person is playing an archetype which does not enable them to fully embody the characters. Downey Jr. is typically charismatic, knowledgeable and confident as Hank but given his speech patterns and line deliveries are derivative of so many of his other characters we're left asking if there is anything more he can do in his sleep. He can still effortless spin one-liners and a few made me laugh, which lightens the film. It is a shame that the talents of Farmiga aren't fully utilised and she could have made a strong fist playing the opposing lawyer, which was given to Billy Bob Thornton who treats the role like he was instructed to be a brooding villain. These are problems typifying the weakness of the film: it feels like we are consciously aware this is a film and a construct because of the script's clichés and the general feel of the movie, where the tone slips away from the director as though he intended to make a broad comedy. No matter what Robert Duvall says, this film is not going to be as big as Apocalypse Now.

Review title: A schmaltzy mess with some geniunely effective moments
Review_body: It's a mishmash of a fine story, subpar writing, good performances and messy directing. It's too long and Vera Farmiga's entire subplot should've been cut.For every really good scene (and there's a lot of really good scenes), there's a scene that makes me go "no, I do not like that".It's a mixed bag, though a rewarding one. It's very flawed, but in the end, I did enjoy it and I do reccomend it, because it's not terrible, it just never quite stops feeling like a corny and schmaltzy, though still somewhat effective melodrama.Watch it and judge (hehe) for yourself.
The film is very solid not much things you can find wrong with it. RDJ was amazing as you'd expect, played the role of cocky perfectly. It was Abit long but that's about it, I very much enjoyed it.
A court drama movie with a good plot and good acting, I highly recommend it.

A high power lawyer Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr) returns to his childhood home to attend his mother's funeral. Upon his return, there is a palpable strained relationship between him and his dad, Judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall). He also is reunited with his brothers Glen (Vincent D'Onofrio) a failed athlete& Dale (Jeremy Strong) who has autism & old flame Samantha Powell (Vera Farmiga) .Hank is desperate to leave ASAP but a turn of event occurs involving his dad scuppers said plan. His dad is accused of the murder of a person that he sentenced to prison & is recently released back to public.The characterisation of this dysfunctional family is very believable especially between Hank and Joseph Palmer. It is a gripping story whereby Hank is trying to save his dad from being found guilty of 1st degree murder and also concurrently he tried to mend bridges between them. So in a way he is fighting on 2 fronts and it is entertaining to watch. The humour is organic and it makes you sit at the edge of the seat until the ending.It is decent enough film but pales in comparison to classic court room films such as A Few Good Men, Philadelphia, etc. The ending is predictable and pulls on your emotional strings just at the right time and place.

Most of today's audiences are really antsy when it comes to character development or impatient when it comes to story. This movie doesn't seem like it worries about people like you. I like the traditional style this movie has. Is it predictable? Somewhat. Dependent on how savvy you are to movies. Is it worthwhile? I think so. It's a fantastic father/son story done with a lot of heart. You can tell everyone involved was invested in making a solid product, blockbuster be damned. What you get is a really poignant family portrait that doesn't pull a lot of punches. Let's say, when James L. Brooks was making battery acid family movies.What I think a lot of criticism is based on for this movie, is a sense of drag. If you don't have family dynamics as combustible as the Palmer family, this may not interest you. I never liked "American Beauty" because I thought that family was dumb. I discovered, that I just don't relate to it. This family dynamic I do. NOT because I've had knock down drag out fights with my father (quite the opposite actually) but because most of the time, we don't see reason as to parenting. We don't necessarily like to eat our peas. In our mind, there is no reason, in theirs they only see reasons. So what you get is a push and pull. Especially between two stubborn bull-headed adults. When their only source of connection is loss, they need to bridge a new gap.This movie isn't about action or plot. It's about family. And I feel it's sorely missing in movies today. Fantastic old school filmmaking

Review title: Mushy Manipulation, Sloppy Judgement - Verdict: Easily Forgettable. Case Dismissed!
Review_body: Reviewed by: Dare Devil Kid (DDK)Rating: 2/5 starsAn overstuffed, overlong slog of a legal drama. "The Judge" wants to be many movies, and fails at being even one of them. I wish I could take Director, David Dobkin, to court and face him as an opposing lawyer. It would be a terrific opportunity to us this argument: "Objection! Meretricious sentimentality! Objection! Badgering the audience! Where is this leading your honor?"This trite melodrama strains so hard to be serious, that it just spirals into a gooey experience, lousy with clichés and rife with been-there seen-that mawkish moments, which might look genuine on paper, but ring false on camera. It could have been a breath of fresh air to see Downey Jr. leave the Marvel universe and Baker Street behind, and remind us all what a terrific dramatic actor he really is. Alas, we'll have to make do with him as "Iron Man" for the time being, as that seems to be the only good role - only really good role - he's landing for now. Even though the film boasts of two stand out performances from Downey Jr. and Duvall, they can do little much to save this hotchpotch of courtroom dramatics and familial dysfunction, neatly wrapped in a conventional package that does whatever it takes to shout IMPORTANT, and, please remember us at Academy Awards time.The only surprise in this long, drawn-out, mushy, clichéd, melodrama is a risqué bit of incest; a refugee from a previous draft, perhaps, that somehow made the screen, possibly at the insistence of Downey Jr, who realized his flick needed a little spice. If you must need, watch "The Judge" just for Downey Jr. and Duvall. Apart from them, there is rarely anything good to take away from this film.

Review title: Duvall & Downey Jnr's courtroom drama of family feuds. More meat than a Grisham
Review_body: The Judge is one of those films they sneak out between the summer blockbusters and the worthy, winter, winning hopefuls; it is too small, too niche to go head to head with the sequels and blockbusters but not quite edgy enough to be a serious contender for gold when we get down to the nitty gritty of the awards season.However, David Dobkin's legal drama is a solid enough flick with plenty to hold the attention and some engaging performances to while away the two hour plus running time. It may not have the tension of courtroom heavyweight A Few Good Men or the gravitas of JFK, but The Judge achieves much as a John-Grisham-with-more-meat production.Hotshot Chicago lawyer, Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jnr), reluctantly returns to his small town, family home when his mother dies. But whereas he makes decent ripples in the city's legal pond, in the sleepy town of Carlinville, Indiana, it is his estranged, outwardly hostile father, Judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) who is the big fish. Eager to see the funeral through and leg it back to Chicago post-haste, Hank is forced to stay when the judge is accused of murdering a former defendant with his car. Despite their mutual dislike for each other, Hank must defend the judge and scrape through the muck and bitterness to the truth of the case and their own family secrets.Like August: Osage County, The Judge is a movie about families tolerating and coming to terms with each other's foibles and reluctantly burying the hatchet, ideally not in one anther's backs, against the backdrop of a forced gathering. The courtroom drama serves to spice up the proceedings and is a great MacGuffin, but the detail is in the relationship between father and son.There are no startling revelations that rock us, just a steady evolution of time and patience as both men air grievances and rail against each other's obstinate manner. Duvall and Downey Jnr make for excellent and watchable sparring partners. Both have been here before but not pitted against each other and this is a marvelous display of Hollywood royalty on fine form.The supporting characters are fluff to give context or a change of shape and pace to The Judge. Each subplot reinforces the complication of family life in its various forms and several of them could easily be the central theme (and frequently have been): brothers with a bitterness based on guilt and regret; long-lost girlfriend (Vera Farmiga as Samantha) who still holds a candle for him; philandering stud consumed by career who rediscovers the attraction of the simple things The Judge is almost a patchwork quilt of ideas, but it works. It is an absorbing film of tenderness and honesty that frizzles with the electricity of family feuds and lightens the atmosphere with occasional, stonking one-liners courtesy of scribes Nick Schenk (Gran Torino) and Bill Dubuque.There are one or two blatantly staged moments (could the outcome of the bicycle ride be any more obvious?) and The Judge takes a half step away from reality in the culmination of the final courtroom scene, but that's forgivable given the outcome and aftermath.Dobkin, whose work as director to date hasn't thrown up anything deeper than Wedding Crashers and The Change-Up, has crafted an attention-grabbing film with a cast that does him great credit. I departed the screening buoyed by the experience and feeling fulfilled. A couple of days later the details are hazy (whereas we can all still quote lines from A Few Good Men) but it remains a positive experience that fades pleasantly and is worthy of a second viewing one day.For more reviews from The Squiss, subscribe to my blog and like the Facebook page.

I really enjoyed "The Judge" but the film isn't without its problems.There's no real surprises going on with the story in this one and the entire film plays out almost exactly like you would expect it. Additionally, the film has some side-stories that aren't that developed and kinda fade away after they get some mild resolution. Finally, a lot of the supporting characters aren't given enough screen time and aren't developed as much as they need to be—and believe me, a lot of these characters seem exceptionally interesting and it's a little heartbreaking to seem them not utilized as well as they should be.However, despite these shortcomings, the film is very charming and, even though it is cliché, the drama and comedy work very well. Finally, you can't ignore how amazing all the performances are in this one. In fact, they are so good that it is easy to ignore any problems this film has and really made it a fun movie that I enjoyed.

There's some good actors in this who give great performances but the story is packed with too many different family story lines. As others have said, it tried to pack in too much. 5/10 does it for me.

Review title: Sappy story about a boy & his father.
Review_body: Semi complicated adventure that was a perfect spiral of down and downer. Than, everything rapped up perfectly.More formulated than I was expecting I think the story was predictable so the movie has to rely in the acting chops of Duvall and Downey Jr to make the characters compelling enough to care about. And I'll give it an A for the acting. The Two Roberts, Vincent D'Onofrio, Vera Farmiga, & Billy Bob Thornton. It was great watching them interact on the big screen with each other. It was a highlight watching the two Roberts interact as father and son. This was so real and emotional.But I'm not all that impressed with the story as a whole. It got too predictable, and that made it boring. Sorry to say.

Review title: Court and law with the Robert's.
Review_body: Two Roberts in one movie about court and law. Should be interesting. The movie is about a hotshot lawyer returns to his how town after his father, the town judge, is accused of murder. While seeking the truth behind the crime, he also tries to reconnect with his estranged family. Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall both did a excellent performance in this movie. I like they back and forward with each other as they are both fantastic actors, and in this movie there's no different that their talent always shines up on the big screen with glory. The writing in the movie was also good and as I said before about the father and son back and forward dialog was written really well, and I got to give Nick Schenk and Bill Dubuque credit for doing that.Vera Farmiga character in the film for me could have been cut out of the movie, she didn't do a terrible job but her character to me slowed the movie down for me and every time she came on screen the movie starts to drag. The movie may not be for everybody. Most people are going to think this movie is dull or boring, but if you are the kind of person who likes to think deep about movies with character's having a drama's or dealing with problems about family or friends then the Judge is your movie. The Judge has two fantastic and brilliant performance be the main Robert's. But the movie may have problems in some scenes of character's dragging the movie down for me, but at the end of the day a movie isn't perfect.

I usually like films like this- legal dramas that are more character- based, and this one delivers! Robert Downey, Jr. stars as a big city lawyer who returns to his small home town to attend his mother's funeral, but then gets involved in his father's (Oscar winner Robert Duvall) criminal murder trial. *possible SPOILER* His dad is the town's big deal judge who has put away many a criminal over the years, and he apparently has run down someone he let free years ago in a drunk driving incident. Did he do it on purpose??- or was it just a drunken accident?? Downey's character meets up with his brothers (including Vincent D'Onofrio) and an old flame (Vera Farmiga), as well as has to sorta coach the inept lawyer handling his father's case toward the beginning- played with amusement by Dax Shepard. Yes, you have a whole list of clichés here, but when they work they work- especially when you have the right case ensembled together. Billy Bob Thornton plays the prosecuting attorney, and he is good as usual, just maybe a tad under-used in the film-?? But the best thing about this film is at it's heart it's a father/son story- Downey and Duvall work well together in a love/hate relationship. Downey blames his dad for not being there most of his life, and Duvall blames his son for some things he may have done that cut short the baseball career of his brother. I would recommend this as good father/son viewing for the upcoming Father's Day holiday weekend...

It is hard to return to home after living in the big time and that is what Hank Palmer finds when he returns home to the funeral of his mother. His father is big figure in this small town. After dealing with family and his mother's death, the judge is accused of murder. Palmer has to swallow his pride and deal with the judge's stubbornness in developing an important defense. This movie has lots of court room drama and the star cast makes for a believable tale. A bit long in a few sections but the high level drama makes for an interesting tale of justice. Downey and Duvall stand out as they play off each other the complex relationship between father and son.

Review title: Nothing new to see here folks (good film and liked it, but not THAT superb)
Review_body: Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall elevate an average and overdone premise into a heartfelt and engaging film in The Judge.Hank Palmer is a big city lawyer on the west coast, and has a tumultuous and strained relationship with his father, a prominent judge in a tiny town. Alas, he returns to his small hometown in the Midwest when his family needs him and tries to restore his relationship with The Judge.All in all, The Judge is pretty unremarkable and quite cliché. Troubled son of a controlling father follows in said father's footsteps in an attempt to prove himself and his worth. Son returns home due to tragedy after long separation and while home old wounds open up, clarity in perspective is attained and contact repaired.The story conceived by Nick Schenk and David Dobkin is far from original and frankly has been done to death. Dobkin further directs the feature film written by Schenk and Bill Dubuque. The cinematography in The Judge is clear, direct but literal and uninspired.It is thanks to Paul Schnee and Kerry Barden that The Judge excels in any notable fashion. The casting of the film is remarkably stellar, enlisting a whose-who of talented actors within their craft. Robert Downey Jr. plays the arrogant city lawyer with a delinquent past. Robert Duvall is the domineering father but well respected pillar of the small community. Even the supporting roles are sublime, with Vera Farmiga, Vincent D'Onofrio, Billy Bob Thornton, Dax Shephard, Jeremy Strong and Leighton Meester round out the cast.The leads are so perfectly cast that the casting single-handedly elevates this average drama to a compelling narrative. The beginning of the film is a bit rough but by the end I was engaged and connected with the characters' transformations.For more reviews of recent releases, please check out our website.

For years I have wanted to see Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr. play in a movie together. Although I never dreamt it would be about a court case. For many years Downey has impressed me for his versatile acting ability to play any role given to him no matter how ridiculous or serious it would be. The film set in the deep southern town where Duvall plays a stern but fair judge becomes a man on the other side of the bench.Downey plays his estranged son who comes back for his mother's funeral but gets stuck for his father's trial seeing as a local man was run down by his car on a rainy night. Emotions gets high when Hank (Downey) tries to help his dad by recalling that night in detail. As memory losses and a failing health condition ensues it starts to call forth doubt as to whether Hank could win his court case at all.I believe this film was excellent because of the high strung characters trying to reconcile differences in light of Hank's father's case even though his father is as guilty as sin. It held aspects of the human condition to where people lose track of themselves in light of what's right or wrong. Duvall played a man of the law to the letter. His performance was brilliant as a man who has nothing to lose for his cancerous condition but for his family it would mean to lose the better part of their lives despite the cost.Seeing a few new roles was a breath of fresh air with Hank (Downey) seducing a local woman who is the daughter of his high school sweetheart Samantha (Vera Farmiga). It had that uncomfortable role where should he tell her what went on between him and Sam's daughter or should he just keep his mouth shut to allow time to pass a bit slower than he would like. For the most part seeing Billy Bob Thornton play a prosecutor is as always wonderful to watch with his linguistic abilities to give a punch line without telling a joke first. His air to play the baddie impresses me even now.For the entire film it was touch and go with emotions, betrayal, reconilitation, heartbreak, and to see Downey play a man who is not afraid to cry. His talents as an actor inspires a great many fans around the world. From his first role to his most recent as a hero who's legacy will live on long after he has left the stage. The judge is an impressive film for court room dramas. I recommend this to all ages above 16.

The Judge is a 2014 American drama film directed by David Dobkin. The film stars Robert Downey, Jr., Robert Duvall, Vera Farmiga, Vincent D'Onofrio, Jeremy Strong, Dax Shepard, and Billy Bob Thornton.Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr.), a brilliant but shady attorney, returns to his Indiana hometown after learning that his mother has passed away. His arrival triggers renewed tension between himself and his father, Judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall), who makes no secret of his disapproval of Hank's morally ambiguous career. As the lawyer prepares to depart, his father is arrested for a hit-and-run death. Hank takes on his father's defense, despite the objections of the resentful old man.

Review title: Extremely well made. Intense, powerful, quality family drama...
Review_body: First off, this is not typically my kind of movie. Although I can appreciate how well made it is, I just don't normally gravitate toward intense family drama, which is what primarily makes up this film.So, I rated it with that in mind; not so much that it will ever be one of my favourite films or that I will ever watch it again, BUT, it is indeed extremely well made and brilliantly acted. I mean, I was frigg'n crying in it more times than I would like to admit (well... I didn't ACTUALLY cry because I am so manly...) So, IF that is your kind of film, then you will totally love it. Just, DON'T go into this movie thinking that it is primarily a 'Courtroom Thriller' or even a 'Courtroom Drama' (for an excellent example of that kind of film, I would highly recommend 'THE RAINMAKER'. A LOT of Drama, BUT also some colourful characters and a LOT of legal courtroom intrigue) Not this one... This one is almost completely centered around the family where Robert Duvall is the father and the judge of the title, and Robert Downey Jr. is his hot-shot, big-city lawyer son.So, if you really enjoy quality films with VERY powerful, intense family Drama, then you should really like this movie.
Of wasting my time with a multitude of unnecessary subplots, get to the point already.. I got to the point I couldn't remember if I cared.Wasted opportunity

A criminal lawyer has to defend his estranged Judge father. This is both a courtroom drama and a family drama.Good writing and very good performance by Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall (who, at age 83, got a nod at the Oscars for this role, just as I expected). With Billy Bob Thornton, Vincent D'Onofrio and Vera Farmiga (I didn't even recognize her).David Dobkin, known for silly comedies, goes in a different way and does a very solid job in directing this drama.I should mention that the movie is 140 min long. Score by Thomas Newman, Cinematography by Janusz Kaminski.According to IMDb's trivia, Jack Nicholson was considered for the role of the Judge. Duvall is great in this role, but I can definitely see Nicholson in it - he could have been great in this (Tommy Lee Jones was also considered, but I don't think it would have worked nearly as good as the other two).

With so much been-there-done-that situations and a slightly over sentimental approach, it was surprising to be actually absorbed and interested in the movie.That would be surely due to the marvelous cast this film offers. They manage to bring some genuine emotion to a movie that would have completely fell flat in the hands of lesser talents. Downey is as charismatic as usual and shows a wide range of depth, getting also the chance to really shine in some scenes. And I'm not talking about the witty banter he goes occasionally off with, which was kind of annoying here and there because it's so expected. I'm talking about some very intimate and realistic scenes with Duvall. Speaking of Duvall, he is the high point of the movie. His performance is simply the proof of one of the greatest actors in cinema history. The rest of the cast rounds up the movie really well without there being any weak links. They keep a story that has some true validity to it alive and flowing well despite a runtime that isn't truly justified. Yet, I must admit I was never bored in anyways and there were some points in which I was genuinely asking myself "Hey, how is this going to go?" demonstrating a true investment in the characters who are built with a lot of detail.This detail is fascinating in parts, but disappointing in others. What I mean is that the clichés in this film are really just too many. The direction certainly doesn't help here because it feels like all of the actors were directing themselves. There is no style, no stamp on this movie. It is very clumsily put together and doesn't have much true energy carrying it. It also fails in part in screen writing, whilst on one side there is a very good story in it on the other the dialogue just feels wrong and out of nowhere a lot of times and other times I actually lost the sense of the scene. That is also probably due to editing which isn't in anyway the brilliant part of "The Judge".I felt pretty captivated by the movie in the theater and had a good offering of a courtroom drama. Yet upon leaving the theater there isn't really anything amazing that sticks out and I think I will probably forget the majority of the film by the end of the year.

Review title: A stellar performance in an epic drama
Review_body: ‎Robert Duvall‬ is outstanding and so is Robert Downey Jr.Little outbursts and disagreements of the duo have been executed brilliantly and framed exceptionally well by ‪Dobkin‬. The bit where Duvall rushes up in high squall carrying a temper whilst Downey follows for war is one of the most dramatic scenes that shows how puny nature is against human commotion! Humour is strewn in the movie and when you have Downey with the bat, it always makes home runs.Drenched with drama the movie has an apt theme that runs around the convicted irony - the Judge who isn't willing to let his guard down and who hates his middle son Downey for so many irreparable reasons that he can't just give in. Whilst Downey, the forlorn child who never returned to his parents owing to the long born and bred abomination he burnt in, tries to save him from the clouded murder of a foul-mouthed obnoxious hill-billy.The score is apt and the screenplay is intense. Loved how Dobkin carried it all. The amount of focus he put in, in every frame is worth commending. A must watch for Downey's wit lovers and also for dramaholics.

Review title: Brings out the jerk in Robert Downey Jr
Review_body: Hank (Robert Downey Jr.) is a big city lawyer who goes home to the small town where he had a textbook unhappy childhood to attend to pretty much every movie trope an adult with a troubled past could imagine: A tough-as-nails dad, a childhood as a delinquent, a girl who might or might not be his daughter, an old flame, a mentally-challenged brother, and a brother who's career ended early. On top of that, there's a court case to win."The Judge" is familiar but deserves some credit for its ambition on paper and it might have at least had a chance at working in practice of Robert Downey Jr.'s character wasn't so difficult to like. Aside from being cordial to his brothers and a doting father to his girl (who isn't?) he lacks a shred of civility to pretty much everyone he comes across with and even casually insults them. He's pure condescension in a bottle. Downey Jr. traditionally plays characters who are rough around the edges but the trait is amplified so much here that you leave this movie not wanting to ever watch one of the films (i.e. "The Soloist") where he hits the sweet spot with that character trait.Nonetheless, the film is definitely bold with how ugly it gets in the father-son relationship. It's certainly not easy to watch but it's something. Certain characters like Dax Shepherd's dim-witted lawyer and Vera Farmiga's Sam shine.The film is likely at its best with the courtroom drama underneath it all although it's somewhat under-served. It gives these unlikeable characters a place to work out their issues.The film is marginally worth watching with but flawed on a number of levels.

Review: I loved this movie because it shows you that people can judge less harshly if they see their struggling child in the eyes of the person on the opposing side. The direction and screenplay are both really good. Both the casting and acting are really good. Especially by Robert Downey JR and Robert Duvall who really fell like they are father and son. All in all I would give this five out of a possible five stars.

Review title: Mostly engaging drama, but needed much suspended disbelief
Review_body: What kind of a guy, even a conceited lawyer, leaves a classic 60's Ferrari for weeks at an airport garage? Hardly any of that million dollar car, if any, would be left upon the owner's return. That was just one of the production values that was not well thought out, along with the Massachusetts locations subbing for Indiana. To me, that's filet subbing for hamburger. Many truths in the film, especially legal, were fudged to make a crowd-pleasing story. (translation.....profitable). There was a lot of "they won't know the difference" in the film. I always catch them at it.But, not to quibble. Yes, the story was contrived to beat the band, but Hollywood does whatever sells tickets, and almost never does encyclopedic truth so that was not surprising, but this was fiction, not a documentary, so that was OK to do if it made for a good story. Still kinda hard for me though, as I expect at least overall believability to engage me for 2 hours. The main actors did not disappoint however, as Downney and Duvall were at the top of their games, with Farmiga not far behind(she is a super talent and looked great). The script was super slick but very predictable, and we all knew what was going to happen at the end, but the film was of such high quality in its beauty shots, technicals and acting, that it mostly overcame its authenticity flaws and crowd-pleasing-ending-above-all to wind up being a mostly rewarding 2 hours. I gave it a 7 out of 10.

Review title: Touching tale of family and redemption
Review_body: I will say that Robert Downey jr gives a rather touching performance playing big city lawyer hank Palmer who finds out that his mother Mary Palmer has recently passed away due to a blood clot and returns home for her funeral. Hank ends up being reunited with his estranged father judge Joseph Palmer played wonderfully by Robert Duvall who ends up being charged with a murder over a client from his prior court dealings, hank agrees to take on his fathers case as a way of not only proving his dad's innocence but also healing the rift between them. Hank also deals with his older brother Glenn who was once a baseball player, his younger mentally challenged brother dale and high school sweetheart SAM.

Review title: A sappy melodramatic film with good performances
Review_body: The Judge stars an all star cast featuring the likes of Robert Downey Jr., Robert DuVall, Ver Farmiga and Billy Bob Thorton and is as surprisingly bad as a film can get. This goes to show that star power doesn't always guarantee a great film. The plot follows Hank Palmer, a stereotypical hot shot lawyer played effortlessly by Downey as he begins to prep for the case of his life, defending his own father, played by Robert DuVall. While the story does sound something like Oscar bait, this film tries to do everything right for all the wrong reasons. Quite frankly, this film is slow, barely touching, but well acted. It seems that Robert Downey, Jr is stuck in a playboy role. He does this so good and so effortlessly that I am hard pressed to give him praise because we've seen this type of character from him countless times. While his performance is good, he can't seem to separate himself from the Tony Stark persona that he has come into within the past seven or so years. Robert DuVall is apparently the go-to actor nowadays for either grumpy old men or estranged fathers with the best advice, both typecast roles he exhibits in The Judge. Much like his co-star, DuVall plays this role effortlessly and has played this role effortlessly for the better part of two decades. Its become old and tired with every film he continues to put out. Despite seeing nothing new from the two, the performances from our leads are good and do keep the film going as best as it can. The real standouts here were the supporting actors. Billy Bob Thorton, Vera Farmiga and Vincent D'nofrio are all fantastic in this and never miss a beat. If there was ever a good enough reason to see The Judge it is for these small handful of performances that stand out and shine brighter than the leads. The plot to the film, while somewhat unique doesn't really pack the type of emotional punch you want it to. Yes, there are sad parts and "que the traditional sappy music" type scenes but these well acted scenes are overshadowed by the sheer redundancy of them. We can only see Hank ask his father a question only to get a snippy answer so many times before we start to question Hank's motives. Why even try? The film doesn't touch base on a clear cut reason to why other than the fact that he's family and he feels obligated to. It didn't touch me on the emotional level I wanted it to. It didn't make me want to call my father after, it didn't make me think at all. I will say that when I saw David Dobkins directed this film, I admired his courageousness to be able to go from a romping comedy such as Wedding Crashers to a film as heavy as this. Despite this big move from comedy to drama, it only showed that Dobkins should stick to comedies. At least he has proved he is VERY good at that. This was an after-thought type of film, one you watch and enjoy to an extent but never really feel as though you want to dissect it or even watch it again. Overall, I was thoroughly disappointed with The Judge as a whole. The film has a couple really brilliant performances namely Vera Farmiga and Billy Bob Thorton but other than these performances, The Judge is a disappointing film that never really taps into anything remotely powerful during its bloated running time.

Really great film with a sad feel to it across the whole film, which is not a bad thing and gets you really into the film and the characters and what's happening in their lives. Great performances all round and I do love court room scenes which some of this film is based in.

One of the three major elements that cripple The Judge, is its slow and awkwardly disjointed start. Robert Downey Jr. is too punchy for a story and script that requires a little bit of a more leisurely approach, and the director Dobkin seemed to struggle to make one scene fit seamlessly into the next; however this issue is way more evident at the beginning of the film.The second problem is, Robert Downey Jr. Though he was really fun to watch, I feel he needs to stay away from witty and charismatic roles for a while, because like it or not, all, or at the very least, the vast majority of what comes across is his alter ego, Tony Stark, and in this movie, a large portion of it felt like Tony Stark having issues with Howard Stark.The third problem is, The Judge tried to squeeze in too much drama, within a movie that somewhat jolted between genres. A dead mother, an accused father who's diagnosed with advanced cancer, a brother with shattered dreams, another with a mental condition and then Hank; estranged, angry, guilt ridden, pompous, divorcee in progress, damaged father, son, husband, brother, boyfriend and lawyer with something to prove and a heart full of pain, in a film that is a family drama turned court thriller back to romantic drama.However, with all of that said, The Judge really did have some amazing moments. The reason why Henry was named Henry. "You got my bit 'o honey old man" gesture. The spinning of the Judge's seat and of course, the real reason why Judge Palmer sent Hank to juvenile detention.The Judge is worth the watch, and if you're a Downey fan, then it's a definite must watch, however, the amazing parts in this film also further highlight how the rest of the movie dropped the ball, which is unfortunate really. 6/10.

Downey Jr. is a household name by now, he played in 3 Iron man movies that made billions of dollars. So the makers of this movie must have thought that putting his name on the movie poster would attract huge crowds? Not really. The film was made for 50m$, without a star like Robert it would have been made for 3m$ and gone straight to TV/DVD. It's half a courtroom drama and half a family coming to terms movie. It looks good and I liked the performances of this club of A-level actors. Billy Bod Thornton is the 'bad' lawyer, but his role wasn't elaborate enough for him to shine. Duvall did a good job and played well against Downey. Nice movie, but not cinema material, more a Sunday afternoon snack to see at home.

Review title: Overrated but not bad,just too long
Review_body: The judge This is one of those small in between movies, that actors do when there's no big blockbuster script available for them. It's basically says that since Duvall's character is a judge, he should be allowed to walk on a hit and run murder charge.Robert Downey play a hot shot lawyer, whose expertise is more or less in defending rich criminals and keeping them out of jail. While he's home for he's mothers funeral, he's dad getting charged with a hit and run murder, So when he's dad get charged for murder, he want to defend him. But he' s dad won't let him, feeling that he shouldn't hide behind a hot shot lawyer if he's guilty, as he feel it would betray he's legacy as a judge After the first lawyer have second thoughts on he's own ability to defend Duvall when the case goes from hearing to trial, he reluctantly lets he's son help defend him.The movie has all the usual clichés. Family feuds ,old girlfriends, divorces, the usual estranged father and son clashes Its way to long. 120+ is to much for these types of movies. 100min would be more than enough the acting is good but the story is just to typical

Review title: Professional Critics are not always right!
Review_body: I was quite astounded/disappointed to find that the general consensus among professional media critics for this film, to be rather less than average (48% rating on Rotten Tomatoes)Yes, this family drama does have its fair share of cliched scenes that have been done to death elsewhere. Which is all very well if you've seen those films. But if you haven't, or simply don't care for such snobbery, then this film is still far more worthy and compelling, not least for the outstanding acting performances from Duvall and Downey Jr.I guess it would have been nice to have learned more about the breakdown between Hank (Downey Jr) and his wife leading to a divorce. All we get is about 3 or 4 minutes with them arguing at the beginning of the film, and then we never see his wife again!Similarly Hank's brief flirtation with Carla (the daughter of Hank's ex girlfriend). We see her in a couple of tangible scenes, but then she too is dropped, never to be seen of again.But those are very minor points. What was hugely enjoyable was Hank's difficulty with adjusting to his family's way of life in small-town America. And in particular his fractured relationship with his dad (Duvall) and two brothers.The courtroom drama with Hank defending his own father (a well-respected former judge in the town), against charges of murder and manslaughter after an RTA, were well done, but very much secondary to the story as a whole.The final scenes were predictable, but nicely done for all that. And the moments in the empty courtroom with Hank spinning the chair belonging to his father is compelling, not least for the excellent song from Bon Iver, called Holocene. The lyrics of which infer that the world does not revolve around you and your ego!Which is a good metaphor for Hank, who considers himself a big-shot lawyer, with an ego to match where he lives in Chicago. But being such a big place you're still fairly anonymous. Whereas returning to his home town, along with building a few bridges, could well mean he make a big and positive difference not just for himself but for those around him.

Review title: The Perfect Movie - Viewer Immursion Guaranteed
Review_body: 01/19/2019 A wonderful movie that speaks to the dysfunctional American family and their fractured relationships. This movie is about a judge, his family and his estrangement from his lawyer son. Compelling and heart warming at times. Great movie. Bon Appetit

Review title: Well, it had some really good parts
Review_body: The main storyline about the Judge being on trial for murder and his relationship with the son as a lawyer were very entertaining and well done, but it was also about the son's relationship with an ex-girlfriend and if he getting custody over his daughter who visits and his relationship with his brothers (who I found boring) and it tried to be too many things. I wanted to like it, but was slightly disappointed. There's a good movie in the script if it was more focused on the trial and the father - son relationship.

Robert Downey Jr returns to his first dramatic acting role since "The Soloist" in this film where he plays an arrogant, sharp tongued lawyer called back in the town that he hates to attend his mother's funeral. His sour relationship with his judge father (Robert Duvall) is further complicated when he is arrested for murder, and he eventually becomes his lawyer to defend him. Throughout the film, both the evidence on Hank Sr, and the tensions between father and son rise up. The acting from both Downey and Duvall is absolutely superb, and the courtroom scenes are a perfect thriller-esque outcome.Downey's character Hank talks fast and talks people down a lot, which made it hard for me to sympathize with him at first. The judge father, a recovering alcoholic, has a very firm attitude towards all three of his sons, which explains the tough exterior for Hank and his brothers. Yet there is immense vulnerability in all of them that eventually comes out during the heated moments.If you want a good family drama to watch the next time you go to the cinema, look no further than this one.
And really good acting all the way through the movie. However the script is a bit boring and Running time definitely too long.

Sometimes, you just watch a movie and you don't really get the point of it. Why was it made except for an obvious desire to make money. I think without a clear intention, a director will rarely achieve a good film. The judge does have good actors, unfortunately, as it often happens it has a very boring and weak storyline. The classic case of a successful son who hasn't seen his parents for over two decades but has to return to the place of his origins for the funeral of one his parents. Due to a turnaround of events, he ends up having to help his father in court as the latter is accused of manslaughter. While the judge could have been entertaining, there weren't any moments that really created tension and the movie ended up being quite dull. I don't know if it's a personal appreciation, but I really feel that most of Robert Downey Jr. movies are utterly boring. I have no idea how this guy came to be the highest paid Hollywood actor. Anyway, whether it is or not personal, don't waste your time with this movie.

"The Judge" is at its heart a movie about parents and children, more specifically fathers and sons, and all the ties that bind us human beings, our connections, relationships etc.However the movie is definitely about 10 to 20 minutes too long. It shouldn't have clocked at more than 2 hours...It is also overstuffed with way too many plots, characters and goings on, so much so, that honestly you might as well get out your notepads and start keeping track of it all...since you will have to in order stay abreast of what is happening on screen...because soo much of it is...almost to the point of "everything but the kitchen sink"! At times, the movie can come off as a bit sanctimonious and self-righteous. Parts of it are unnecessarily overwrought and melodramatic and do nothing to add to it, but further burden it for no good reason.But, and it is a rather large and big "but", the excellent acting, primarily by Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall, save this movie from becoming an unwanted clunker.So if you want to see an acting tour de force by two good actors, and a decent supporting cast, then this movie might be for you. If you don't want your head spinning from "too muchness" and want to avoid falling into a deep depression, or are already suffering from one, then I'd suggest staying away...

This is a really well written drama, with some great dialogue and despite it's length is well paced and keeps the attention. I also found it to be very moving and a realistic portrait of a dysfunctional families dynamics. It's an adult film with very grown up themes, but also has moments of great humour and pathos. An unexpectedly intelligent treat, which is so rare these days.

Big city lawyer Hank Palmer returns to his childhood home where his father, the town's judge, is suspected of murder. Hank sets out to discover the truth and, along the way, reconnects with his estranged family. The Judge is directed by David Dobkin and stars Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall. It's cool to see Robert Downey Jr. in a role that doesn't involves him putting an iron suit on. This man has talent, he actually is an excellent actor, I recommend to check out some of his movies from the 90's to early 2000. Of course Robert Duvall was in To Kill a Mockingbird, he's a fantastic and iconic actor since for ever. This movie is exciting. Firstly I'm impressed; not only this film is funny but it's also very interesting, an almost two and a half hours movie and you are never bored. That's what I called Cinema. Though, there is nothing original about the story but it does focus a lot on hi characters. Plus, Robert Downey Jr. is excellent in this film; he steels every scene he's in and that's pretty the whole movie. As I said before, it's good to see him again playing an adult male character other than Iron Man, he's great as Iron Man but this actor can do serious adult drama movies and killed it as well. It reminds me of Zodiac. It's also great to have Robert Duvall back because for the past few years he was just a cool supporting actor showing up for few scenes and that's pretty much it; but here he's GOOD! Vincent D'Onofrio is terrific in the movie as well as Billy Bob Thornton who is the "bad" guy but he's just doing his job, he's underused. However, on the one hand there are some intense and powerful scenes between the two protagonists but in the other hand some are a bit cheesy and unrealistic. Everything involving the girl and her daughter in the movie could have been erased. It's evolving around this father and son emotion, you don't really need her. Vera Farmiga is a good actress but it won't miss something if they skip it, I would even say that this is a little irrelevant to the overall plot. Finally, I feel like there weren't enough of the court room scenes, that are my favorite ones; they keep showing those a bit boring and useless family drama dynamic argument when the main plot take place around this super interesting case. Overall The Judge is an effective and well directed movie with performances that all are very good, the story is very interesting, showing family bonding and doing something good for the world as when you walk out of this movie, the only thing you want to do is call your father.

You have to see this one it is so good. Great story line and of course great acting from the 3 mains here. Duval, downie and thornton. A dream cast. Duval excells in his role. No idea how i missed this one first time round. I didnt think it was too slow or too long. There wasnt a wasted moment in this film . A must see!

I mean this in a good and positive way. I struggled with this movie due to the family strife that I have been apart of. I could watch it again though. I can't believe here it is 2021 and I am just seeing this movie. Great performances, all the way around with all actors. This movie was loaded with incredibly gifted actors.I see it has only received a 7.4 overall IMSB rating, I could not rate it any lower than my 10, and I didn't know what its rating was until after I had viewed it.WOW!!!!!!!

This film had all the right ingredients to make it big. A promising basic premise, excellent actors & good background score. What it lacked, unfortunately, is originality. A holier-than-thou judge who has always handed out just punishments to other people finds himself accused of a crime he doesn't remember committing even though there seems to be a mountain of circumstantial evidence to that effect. His son, the big city lawyer, steps in to save dad's reputation.The actors have all done a great job but the script was a bit of a drag and could easily have been streamlined a bit so as to make it more effective. Some scenes were quite superfluous & could have been removed like the deeply personal discussions between the lawyer & his 'client' on the witness stand. Also, the hint of incest was unnecessary & didn't contribute much to the story. The scene with the breaking into the cafe was also unnecessary. Who wants to see grownups behave so irresponsibly? Couldn't the ex-girlfriend simply state that she owned the cafe?The movie is very watchable to all those who appreciate good acting. I just wish that the editor & director were equally good.

A good performance by Duvall, but whilst Downey Jr was good in the various relationship roles he did not convince as an attorney and for me this undermined the film.The scenes with the weak and and inexperienced lawyer did not sit well in this film. This was no fault of the actor it was just silly plot. It worked in the excellent "My Cousin Vinnie" but was all wrong here.Overall there are too many story lines going on, many of them sketchy and bitty so not adding anything substantive to the film.

-The Judge is a film starring Robert Downey Jr who is a really hard-case lawyer known for defending guilty clients. When his mother passes away, he is forced to confront his father, a judge played by Robert Duvall. When his father is accused of a serious crime, RDJ attempts to get over the destroyed relationship with his dad to defend him in court.-So The Judge was pretty good. It had a pretty good story, but it was not the most engaging movie of the year.-The acting was great. RDJ did a great job, but I think Robert Duvall is looking at an Oscar nomination. Maybe. Also the supporting cast was very good too.-The pace was slow. I'll be honest, it is not the most exciting movie, and that is saying something considering The Drop was not about much and I loved it. However The Judge had the usual pace of a law film and/or a father/son relationship film.-Aside from a few that this film offered, it was pretty real. Some of the issues going on, especially physical illness, was tough to watch in a good way. It did not skimp anything that helped the story. Until the end, which was eh. Hey, ending was better that The Maze Runner! -The music was good. Just listen to Saving Mr. Banks. Same composer. Same music pretty much.-I know I have said a few negatives, but the film was pretty good. It had some REALLY grainy shots, but that was not enough to sink Tony Stark and "I Love the Smell of Napalm in the Morning" hashing out their relationship.-Content: The film is rated R for mild language including some sexual dialogue. That's how it sounds. Not heavy on much, but some language.-So to sum it up, The Judge was a little bit of a downer because of its slower pace and realistic storytelling, but it is a solid film with great acting a good story to tell. I would say that if you are interested in seeing these two Oscar nominees in a well written film that will depress you a little, it is worth seeing in theaters. If you are in for a funny film with RDJ as a judge then wait until you see it in a $5 bin. My rating: 7/10.

Review title: A guys' story - Real and raw to the bone!
Review_body: Seeing the trailer, the movie really captivated me with the tension it conveyed. I was really intrigued to watch this particular father- son relationship, not to mention the mystery about the father's crash. I was rewarded for every minute of watching the movie and it has really been quite some time since I watched a movie that was so sound in terms of storyline and script. The characters were portrayed vividly by the actors and it was a really balanced cast in terms of performance. What could anyone say really about the performance of the father or the one given by Robert Downey Jr? This guy really evolves and progresses all the time.. I really liked the small parallel stories that went on, making you really focus on each one as the film progressed, in a way that you sort of forgot what was going on in the other stories, until time came to get the update on them as well. The accident, RD's marriage, RD's affair, his alleged daughter, etc. I was really moved by the role of the mentally challenged brother. This was a guy that had his own problems but he was always a voice in each situation that said out loud what others would not because of social "musts" or their own discretion. He was a constant reality-check throughout the movie.The end was a perfect wrap up and the final moments of the movie were both breathtaking and devastating. Seeing a 75-year old servant of the law getting out of prison with his health greatly deteriorated, the fishing trip with the son, the change in his behavior towards him, all of these. It is amazing how all the characters evolved through the movie into a better version of themselves and how in the end, even death came at such a sweet way, if I may say so. A movie filled with moral lessons and with moral dilemmas for that matter. It's a movie where sides cannot be picked easily and where the catharsis comes in the end for everyone but mainly for the father-son duet. It's really really a must watch!

Although it's true that Duvall's performance is quite fine, you have to pull teeth to get the plot to move along. If someone suggests you see it, tell them you'd rather go to the dentist... less painful. It's 2 1/2 hours of misery. Every sentimental, sanctimonious cliché is paraded for your viewing and they drip with saccharine homilies and superiority. The slick lawyer who leaves the big city to defend his demented father who is a judge and who hates his son because he's very successful, albeit defending criminals... isn't that what lawyers do? They don't all defend people whose dogs poop in a petunia bed. I genuinely hated this movie. I turned it off once to watch something else. I went back to it and finally fast forwarded the "love story" which was boring and hackneyed, along with the dear "cute" little daughter scenes. Can't say enough bad about this clunker.

Review title: An Impact-full Father-Son Relationship followed by Solid Performances by Downey Jr. & Duvall
Review_body:
A father-Son problematic relationship surrounded by legal drama where Henry Palmer a ruthless lawyer in Chicago played by Robert Downey Jr. and his father Joseph Palmer The Judge played by Robert Duvall and how circumstances brings them together again.
Despite of fair screenplay and direction all praises goes to Downey Jr. as he always impresses with hi wit and sarcastic one liners which you can clearly see in trailer also if you go through with that and Robert Duvall with his impressive performance as aged judge who is accused of some hit and run case.
Although film got mixed reviews from critiques one thing at which all had their consensus was the performances by the leads and that is why I am recommending this movie to watch

Review title: Robert Downey Jr.'s Failed Attempt At Branching Out
Review_body: The Judge commences with a usually cocksure Robert Downey Jr. as Chicago's successful lawyer, Hank Palmer, who's just one of those you despise—the one who gets the affluent guilty off scot-free. He has left his hometown of Indiana and family behind years ago in pursuit of a career before his mother's death finally reunites him with his family once again: a father who's a judge of righteousness and integrity (Robert Duvall); a phlegmatic and mentally slow brother (Jeremy Strong); and a more strong-willed, mindful brother (Vincent D'Onofrio). Many old friends and, especially, his father are angered by his sudden desertion those decades ago, and consequently, Hank feels alienated upon his return and deeply frustrated with these complicated dynamics. In a legal family, the concept of forgiveness seems to be elusive. That is until Hank's father—a long reigning and revered judge, mind you —is accused of murder when a spatter of blood is found on his vehicle and the body of a murderer he strongly despised is discovered on the same road he drove down the previous night. Hank becomes wildly conflicted, unable to let go of the exhaustion and issues with his dad but also not buying a minute of these severe accusations. He forgets about Chicago and stays behind to defend his father in court, standing by the defendant in a criminal case yet again. Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall are the obvious standouts here, and if any aspect of this film is worth the viewing, it's these two performances—competently acted through the various extreme emotions necessary as they struggle to coexist in the same house and tryingly fight through this case. Downey is frequently smarmy and smug to no surprise, but he's additionally allowed to effectively convey plenty of pensiveness and dejection. In the meantime, several distressing scenes show Duvall at his absolute physically worst as a dying man of cancer— crawling for dear life, vomiting, (realistically) defecating in his underwear as his son despairingly holds on. At the same time, there's some talent in the cast that are either wasted or honestly unnecessary. I'm not sure Vera Farmiga's role, Samantha Powell, was meant to be anything but the standard romantic interest/emotional support during a predicament that Hollywood needs to implement into their scripts for the sake of a female character's inclusion. After witnessing Gone Girl, the amazing and rich female character that is Amy only materializes just how awfully bland most productions make its females appear. The nostalgically romantic, sexy scenes between Downey and Farmiga offered very little, and alas extended the already-protracted runtime with its garrulous nature. On a more positive note, the impressively stark black-and-grey colors and theatrical lighting of Janusz Kaminksi's cinematography, allowing for the true vibrancy of a courtroom's hue, elevates the story beyond something that could've easily been reserved for the Lifetime channel. One of my favorite composers, Thomas Newman, inserts his typical elegiac, stirring score except that it seems transparently manipulative here, unfortunately. Every moment of overt sentimentality is accompanied by a quiet, weeping piano.Emotionally explosive scenes of compelling dialogue are occasionally dispersed throughout this otherwise painfully overlong, syrupy melodrama. You can expect an abundance of crying and yelling, as well as overdone family drama on the side that's all too predictably resolved. In the end, The Judge isn't the best next project for Downey in his attempt to branch out from superhero movies.

Some of the very best acting from some of the very best actors in the business. Robert Duvall, Robert Downey Jr., Vincent D'Onafrio, Billy Bob Thornton.and Jeremy Strong was no slouch portraying the younger brother with 'issues'. This is probably the best movie I've seen all year, and I've seen a lot of them. A film dealing with family matters of various sorts, some of which so many of us can relate to as we've more or less been there, done that. A picture with that much acting perfection, that much power all wrapping around a good story line, good plot believable dialogue  I don't think a movie fan can ask for more. And, no spoiler alert here, the ending is one where you can imagine it being the more-or-less happy, fairy tale ending (which I did) or...it's all up to you. Me – I'm all about happily ever after endings - I went away with one future in mind, you may or may not share mine. Up to you. At any rate, this is a fantastic film with some of the best acting you're going to see this year.

Review title: Not As Good As It Should Have Been
Review_body: Really looked forward to this film, although newspaper reviews were lukewarm, since I have always liked courtroom type stories. (My father was a lawyer). And with actors like Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr., how bad could it be? Answer: Not bad, really, but still disappointing. First, it was soooo long, nearly two-and-a-half hours, while the story wasn't all that complicated. Second, the script was what I call overwritten, meaning that much of what was said was very complex and sounded contrived, yet spoken very quickly, so it made me feel that the actors were just reciting their lines, not speaking from the heart. I think Duvall was better than Downey overall, as I find his glib style, similar to his awkward moments in "Chef", to be annoying after awhile, even obnoxious. Plus it was fairly predictable, even though it took almost forever to get there.

Quickie Review:After the death of his mother, lawyer Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr.) returns to his hometown. During the visit his estranged father, the judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) is suspected of murder. As the case unfolds and the wounds in the family revealed, Hank has the opportunity to mend those broken relationships and reconnect with his family. The Judge is emotional and deeply touching, and it's all thanks to the acting powerhouse Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr. That alone is reason enough to watch the movie. It is slightly too long and some characters are not well utilized, but as a whole this is a solid movie.Full Review:Just looking at the cast I knew I had to give The Judge a shot, and for the most part I was right. Like I previously mentioned the two leads are what makes the movie work. On the other hand there are some cast members I would've liked to have seen more of and others a little less.Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall are the ones who brought the somewhat clichéd estranged father story-plot to another level. Both their characters are extremely stubborn, clinging on to old events as an excuse to how they behave. Hence whenever they are at odds with each other they bring an emotional weight to the scene. So much so that you actually feel the weight, and you might want some room to breathe because of how tense a scene was. Fortunately the audience does get some break from time to time thanks to its pacing and subtle humor sprinkled where appropriate. Also you are not always bogged down by the family drama, there is also a thriller element to the movie that is engaging during the court room sessions. Downey's charisma really shines during the court hearings because of the command he holds in the room.Where the movie fails is how it handles some of the supporting cast. Vera Farmiga's character for example is supposed to be the love interest for Downey. A lot of time is actually spent on their relationship. But that subplot keeps going around in circles and never leads to anything. Perhaps it is meant to show other relationships Hank is mending, but you won't care about that as much as how things are between him and his actual family. So to be honest that whole subplot and character could've been removed and it wouldn't have made a difference. Another example of mishandling a character is the one played by Billy Bob Thornton. He plays the lawyer Downey is up against, but the entire movie Thornton felt more like spectator than a serious threat to the leads. I would've loved to have seen them both clash heads in the court room, but unfortunately that never happens.Despite the mishandling of the supporting cast, The Judge is a strong movie. There have been many estranged family stories in the past, but rarely has the emotional depth that this movie has. So if you are on the edge or undecided, I'd recommend giving it a shot.Check out more on my movie review blog The Stub Collector: http://thestubcollector.wordpress.com/

This is probably not what you expect. Not really a crime centered movie, not an action movie. This is about a family redemption drama movie. A conflict between a son and his father, a sly lawyer and a ethical judge. And it is absolutely well done under any aspect, very well crafted and interesting till the end, despite the duration. It is moving as well if you are inside family dramas. Actors were all great, Duvall an Oscar worthy.Originality: 8 (Could be not the first) Plot: 9 (the story about father and son troughs a crime) Characters: 10 (all actors were great)Dialogue: 8 (it is centered in it but not memorable) Pacing: 8 (gripping anyway despite the slow evolving) Cinematography: 10 (Just perfect) Direction: 10 (Perfect) Entertainment Value: 10 (Moving, deep and mesmerizing) 9.1/10 Highly suggestedThank you for reading, Regards

'The Judge' is not a bad film. Its quite enjoyable with its strong cast, beautiful camera-work and great performances. What needed polishing is obviously the thing in which most movies fall short - the writing. The estranged son returns home and reunites with his family plot is nothing new. Still it could have pull out of the clichéd screenplay with great characters and dialogues. To some extend it succeeds but with the tiring length of almost 2 and half hours 'The Judge' fails to grasp your attention. The performances are great, the duo of Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall have done a fascinating job. I was very much hooked half-way through despite the clichés. But as the obvious truths begin to reveal in second half , it felt bland. The length really made it boring. Things get overly-sentimental and the screenplay follows a predictable path. In the end, it was mixed bag for me. If you are a RDJ fan or would like watch great performance by him and Duvall, you may end up liking it otherwise it's just another drama for a lazy afternoon viewing.RATING: [2.5/5]

Review title: One of the best family drama movie
Review_body:
The title of the movie could mislead people because it's more than a crime and courtroom movie it's more deep than these, full of emotions and at the end of the movie you start to think about the value of the family as movie successfully dig deep about it
Amazing acting with wonderful directing and most beautiful filming locations and sights.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was stripped back and emotionally solid. The performances from Downey Jr and Duvall were excellent and their relationship unnerving. The families past and misunderstanding is all a little soap opera like but the way its delivered is to the highest standard. Whilst Downey Jrs typical wit was present, a quick talking lawyer was a well suited character and it was refreshing to see him in more of a dramatic role. I felt it was a little drawn out but its ending was bold and memorable.

The leading performances were nothing short of excellent. I won't be surprised if Duvall gets an Oscar nomination - his acting here is very impressive. Downey Jr. is also impressive, and so are D'Onofrio and Strong. All in all, the cast is great and if you watch the movie specifically for its acting, you won't be disappointed.Kaminski's camera work is also award worthy. This guy is one of the best cinematographers in the business and although 'The Judge' is far from his best works, it still looks great.Dobkin's directing is serviceable, although it is far from great.The music is mediocre at best. I have some experience as a musician and a composer but I can barely remember any of it.The writing is just a bit better than the music, and that is the movie's biggest problem. At first glance it looks well written but that is only because the actors are giving their best, and then some. As a drama about a dysfunctional family it works. It isn't nearly as great as it could have been but it works. As a courthouse drama it falls flatter than a pancake. Right on its face, I might add. The only thing it manages to show is that the American justice system is about as useful as... something completely useless. Given Downey's last line, I think this is exactly what the people who made the movie didn't want to show. I don't want to spoil it but what happens to Duvall's character is a direct consequence of his own stupidity. Not pride, although the writers probably thought they made his pride the main reason for what happened. Just stupidity. And that is not the only problem. As the movie goes on, you get to see or hear about some really impossible stuff - one of the central points of the drama involves such a huge conflict of interests... It just can't happen in real life and it sends the movie's realism down the drain. Honestly, it felt like the writers had drawn all of their inspiration from some TV-show rather than doing some actual research on the matter. There is the same rhetoric we have seen in all courthouse drama movies. Again, what we saw gave me the impression that all American lawyers are taking extensive acting lessons. And there is exactly the same - and rather forced - dramatic situation of the jury telling their decision we see in every movie with a lawyer as a main character. There are also a few intentionally comedic scenes that just do not fit the overly serious tone of the movie.Overall, the movie is very watchable. But that is all thanks to the actors and the cinematographer. The writing is forced, predictable and unrealistic, and it is far from the best in the genre.

I hardly rate 8 or 9 but this movie is solid 10. Star studded movie. Great direction, great writing, and great acting! Downey Jr, Duvall, Farmiga, and Thornton are just impeccable! I can watch over and over again.

Review title: No matter how dark it gets, family is always there
Review_body: This movie was more than just the murder trial at hand. It was molded around the value of family. It did an excellent job telling the story.Judge Joseph Palmer, played by Robert Duvall, is a respectful member of his community. He was the judge for 42 years, married for 50 years, and had successful children. Due to unforeseen circumstances, his wife passed away and it led to a road of mischief. The night after his wife's death, the judge had ran into one of his former convicted felons who was released from prison after a 20 year sentence. That felon was found dead on the side of the road, and his blood on the judge's vehicle grill.Attorney Hank Palmer, played by Robert Downey Jr., is the judge's middle son. Hank and his father did not have the greatest of all relationships. Despite their shaky relationship, Hank was brought in to represent his father in the murder trial.The trial took place for most of the movie, but that really was not the main focus. The main focus was more towards the value of family. Hank and his father were trying to put their differences aside in a time of need. It was not easy, but they made it through it. As the trial kept nearing the end, more of their previous problems were let out and expressed. Now that they were both much older from when their problems occurred, they were able to reconcile their differences.The trial did not end as what one would have thought. Judge Joseph ended up having to serve time, but it was not anything to severe. Once he got out, he and Hank were together, but things were much more peaceful this time around. It was good to see a father and son find peace with one another. After all, families are always supposed to stick together.

What happened to the movies? What happened to Hollywood? They used to be professionals. They used to be able to take the skimpiest of plots and flesh 'em out at minimum into a watchable film that had some kind of point. This thing, however, looked like it was drafted on a cocktail napkin on Tuesday night at the pizza parlor and then assigned to a series of crew members picked at random from the back of a cereal box. The acting does not 'save' the movie, it shows it for what it really is. Confused, dreary, maudlin and by the time it resorts to the precocious little girl to stall for time, ya know you're looking at a real stinker. I was waiting for ol' Shep the family dog to make an appearance and eat up another ten minutes. Guess ol' Shep had some pride though, he didn't show up. Cash the checks, keep your name in front of the audience and the people who call the shots in Hollywood. Is the last movie you made any good? No? Well, cash the check and move on to the next project. Who will know the difference? Cash the check and run. As for us, the paying members of the industry, the ones who get up, go out on a rainy night to see a movie and expect to be presented with a coherent storyline, competent acting, good production values and .. the bottom line.. for our good money.. ENTERTAINMENT we'll keep the money next time. Maybe one of the checks will bounce and somebody will wake up.

Review title: sit back and enjoy Mr. Duvall...and some good scenes
Review_body: pretentious, predictable, past its' time film, which should have been a classic. but no....gender correctness and over-sexedness and downright crudity (a lot of vomiting) screw it up, or should I say DOWN to FIVE stars.resolution for this reviewer was distressingly bad. plus, we are further abused by having to watch add-on scenes just when we expect "The End". the director, whoever, just can't deliver a more satisfying "hollywood ending".. he just has to take the long way home.Robert Duvall seems to enjoy playing the small town Judge who never could balance his professional and personal life...and now faces an even bigger challenge. his health is failing. and he must rely on his least favorite son to get him out of a very serious mess he made! how *responsible* was he in a fatal car crash?

This is watchable but that's about it. No surprises and typical US drama, but Robert Jr, he's almost unwatchable as is SO arrogant. I think that's just him in real life and he can't tone it down when acting. He just look in the mirror and lick himself. Spoilt the film really.

When it comes to family relationships, cinema always has something to say. David Dobkin's dramatic work also has something to say, although not necessarily new.
The story is about a small town judge, who is charged with murder on the same day that his wife passes away. Against this background, his children, especially his son Henry, will have to do everything possible to defend him.
It is as well as this history is outlined like a judicial one, but that really comes to be a familiar story. A powerful family drama that covers different edges, perhaps too many and many do not end up fitting into the story. However, the truly important relationship ends up being that of the judge with her son. A story is drawn where the relationship of both is the support of the story, beyond the judgment itself. And this support is also helped by the great performances of Duvall and Downey Jr., two Roberts who give this film an authentic emotionality.
'The Judge' is a story of family relationships, of a slow but effective narration. Although it is sometimes a bit cliché, this can be left out due to the emotionality it contains.

Review title: Good performances by Downey and Duvall
Review_body: Really a sentimental melodrama more than hardcore courtroom fare, The Judge is overly long and has a subplot concerning Downey's character and an ex girlfriend that wastes screen time and adds nothing to the story.Nevertheless, Downey demonstrates why he is one of the best actors of his generation. Duvall, whose legacy has long been established, doesn't coast on his reputation. He plays his character to the max.Good supporting performances by Vincent Donofrio, Billy Bob Thornton, and Dax Shepard.Movies like this that lack fast action and are not greatly suspenseful depend on our ability to identify with the characters.
