Review title: You HAVE TO see this movie, guys.
Review_body: The film was directed by David Dobkin, which is I've never watched any of his films BUT I liked this one. It stars Robert Duvall as Joseph Palmer(The Judge) and Robert Dawney JR. as his son, Hank Palmer. The film won three award in 2014 for the Icon Award (Robert Duvall), Supporting Actor of the Year(Robert Duvall) and the director won Truly Moving Picture Award. The film is set in the fictional town of Carlinville, Indiana. Scenes filmed in Pennsylvania and Worcester, Massachusetts.The film is about a father and a son. Hank Palmer is a succesful defense attorney in Chicago and he is getting divorce. His brother calls Hank to tell him their mom is dead. Hank goes to the Carnville, the place where he spent his childhood. He joined his mothers funeral. Hank ve The Judge's relationship is complicated, it seems like they don't like each other. After the funeral, Hank was on his way to Chicago, his brother called him and tell him that his father is accused with murder someone. So he is back for his father to defense him at the court. End of the movie, they lose the case, Joseph goes to prison for 7 seven months, then Hank find a way to get him out of prison. Joseph dies when they are on a boat and fishing.I strongly recommend The Judge. It has a strong drama and a crime movie, so if you love kind of movies, you should see it. There is also a very strong message : "No matter what happens, family is everything and even though they have faults - like all people have - we should embrace them instead of keep distance beetwen them."

Super film that will have you gripped, not because of the court room scenes which take a side story to the main purpose of this film, but seeing a family struggle and come together when needed. The acting is excellent, not just from the principles, but also to the strong supporting cast..... The bath scene is moving and a pivotal part in a complex relationship.Yes there's similarities to other movies, yes there's plot holes and more questions then you may heard asked, you may guess the plot early, but watch it play out and challenge yourself not to be moved by the well paced, well acted movie.

This movie might seem good, if you were born yesterday and never saw a movie before. Forget what you know about Duvall, Downey Jr., or even Billy Bob. Everything about this movie was a tired cliché. Cue the cocky black sheep returning home and finding his roots again, to the simple well-meaning brother with a camera, contrasted by the understands-too-much-for her age 12 year old girl that still calls her parents "mommy and daddy" to every single small town stereotype that you can think of. Then of course the now-humbled redeemed black sheep returns to his shiny life with a new humbled outlook. But makes it home in time to go fishing with the 'old man' one last time. And of course they have a touching father-son moment right before the father dies on the boat. Flag flies at half staff ("no one says half mast anymore"). Guy gets girl he left behind. I wish I could tell you that the cheesy 'feel good moments' ended there. Sadly they didn't. Take my word for it. Do not waste your time.

I don't get it. Why so many negative reviews? Like seriously, it doesn't make sense. First off, that was the best acting I've seen in a while. Robert Duvall is definitely like top 4 greatest actors of all time imo. Tbh I wasn't expecting such a great performance from RDJ tho. Beautifully shot, scored and written. I can care less about 141 minutes as long as it has great performances, screenplay, cinematography, a good score and The Judge had it all. People just like to hate on stuff for no apparent reason.

Great film with fine performances from all involved. Especially the 2 Roberts.
I'll never tire of watching this film.
Each to their own.
I love the evolution of both characters during the film, both Robert's outstanding performances are worthy to watch.

This movie had it all. It began as a sad story about a successful lawyer returning to his hometown (Downey Jr.)after his mother's death, to a place with so many bad memories but more importantly to a place where his father lives and works, a father he hasn't spoken to for many years. But in the end the movie was so much more than that.The acting is excellent. Robert Duvall is truly wonderful here as the lawyer's father and THE judge. I do believe this could be his Oscar worthy performance.As for Robert Downey Jr. I thought he was a very good comedian (which he gets to practice in this movie as well) but he is so much more. I truly have more appreciation for the man's acting capabilities. Also, an Oscar worthy performance.The messages are many. I found that the movie tried, and succeeded with flying colors, to mash up together a murder story and a story about family and how to break the chains and walk out of their shadow and ultimately a story about life, death and revenge.The punchlines come when you least expect them and for a drama movie there are a lot of funny lines, perfectly given by the two lead men, who literally take the movie on their shoulders and carry it on until the finale.Speaking of finale, you keep guessing what actually happened, as the director made sure we watched the movie from the judge's point of view. We, like the judge, are clueless as to what really happened and if we (the judge) did really commit the murder. The shots are beautiful and especially the court scenes are both shot and played to perfection. The underline messages are so much more (which I can't go into detail) but I give high praise to Robert Duvall's acting. I highly recommend this movie. I think the buzz is just beginning and I expect the movie to be at least on 6-7 different categories in the Academy Awards Ceremony (including Best Director, best Leading actor, best screenplay and best cinematography). If you are a fan of great story telling, wonderful acting and a close to perfect directing then this is the movie for you.WATCH IT AT ALL COSTS

I was able to see this before the October release and although I read some of the reviews that were released recently I started to have some reservations however, I have disagreed with some critics in the past and figured I'd make up my own mind about this film. Gratefully I did not have to worry because it was time well spent. The performances were excellent and it was witty as well and engaging. When looking at the posters (without giving much away) I got the impression that this film looks like something out of a John Grisham novel or an episode of Law and Order, and while there is the trial going on, the movie is more of a focus of this man's (Downey) relationship with his father (Duvall), his family, his unresolved issues with his present life and the life he left behind. Downey and Duvall don't disappoint as well as the ensemble cast. If you're looking for a movie with heart, engaging performances and not a "courtroom drama", this is definitely the right film.

I really don't understand how critics call this title's script formulaic. This is a unique movie with fitting atmosphere. (Nice scores from Thomas Newman too.) It has excellent character development. Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall did their jobs very well. And the more you find out about the supporting characters, the more you know about the two main ones. I have to be honest. This is not a movie for everyone. Is this for grown-ups? Perhaps. It is not about epic battles or fancy dialogues. It is a movie that will make you reflect on how you value your family. I would say this should be a required viewing for all sons and fathers.

Review title: Definitely worth seeing for two amazing performances from Downey and Duvall.
Review_body: I saw this film twice at TIFF and was quite impressed! It's getting some harsh reviews, undeservedly. Yes, it's too long and yes, director David Dobkin needs to work on his tone and pacing, but the story is great and the performances are fantastic! Not a simple courtroom drama at all, the story is more about Hank Palmer (Downey)'s struggle to understand his relationship with his father and to accept where he came from. It's about identity, family, and all the messiness and contradictions of life. If you are a teenager who can't sit still through a more-than-two-hours long movie, or expect some type of John Grisham or Iron Man-like action from this film, you will be disappointed. If you are a true film lover who revels in watching great actors practice their craft, you will not be disappointed by The Judge. This movie is definitely worth sitting through for amazing performances by both Downey and Duvall, who could both be up for Oscar nominations for their roles as the son and father, respectively. There are many very funny moments as well as many touching moments between father and son, brother and brother. The audience I sat with at Roy Thomson Hall loved it, frequently expressing their appreciation with laughter. See for yourself on October 10--don't let a few critics spoil it for you.

First the good things about the movie: => Great Cast and good movie characters. => Is a little bit close to reality, so those who see themselves in the movie character may enjoy the movie more. => You can count in the movie if you make a list on father-son relationship!!!Coming to bad things in the movie: => The movie is discontinuous and do not touch all the plots planted in the movie. => The movie is not clear in what it wants to convey or portray.Overall, it is a good movie. Not much of a thinking is required. May touch your emotional spot for a second. There is hardly any romance in the movie. Can be graded as a typical family drama movie.
The artestry of Robert Duval and the incredible humanically comedic suditally that only Robert Downey Jr provides brings this story together.A true enjoyment to have.

The most beautiful movie! The relationship between Father and Son, well portrayed... I must say, it deserves an Oscar or Oscars, brilliantly amazing acting. I am totally cherished, wow, though it got emotional scenes, must say it's totally dramatic. This movie is long but a worth watching masterpiece. The song at the end of the movie is "Coldplay - Scientist". Man! this is what i called a Dramatical amazing movie... Furthermore, i have seen Downey's other movies in which he jokes around but this movie is something else it has some happy moment and some emotional tears. It is a journey of emotion between two people who loves each other yet, don't know how to express that unconditional love between a father and a son, just a great story line, and a great movie!

I have picked to watch that movie as like Robert Downey Jr.. Ddin't expect it to be such an extraordinary and deeply touching movie... Actors- Downey Jr., Robert Duvall,Dax Shepard...these are the names they speak for themselves and they proved it in "The Judge". So many important subjects spoken about:difficult family relations...tough father-son love...coming back to your childhood town...parents passing away...etc... And it wasn't only melodramatic all the time...Amusing too...and keeping you focused all the time.. Great music too- Willie Nelson, whom I didn't know existed..Definitely watch again in the future...

It's been a while since a movie has grabbed me from beginning 'till the end. I was hooked, couldn't turn it off even if I wanted to. Brilliant dialogues and fantastic atmosphere between Duvall and Downey Jr. Holy moly this was a great movie.Every scene was carefully weighed and very well executed, I love how the dynamic of the family really comes out the further in to the movie you go. They even managed to incorporate comedy. Robert Downey Jr. was really charming and sometimes even amicable. Duvall really had the sympathy-factor going for him. Every other role in the movie was in my opinion absolete, it was enough for Duvall and Downey Jr.Would I recommend this to everybody? Yes! Every movie lover, even the slightest movie lover, should watch this movie and be Downey-fied.

Review title: Easy on the head .........tugs at the heart.
Review_body: I simply loved this film. Its well cast and believable. I felt the real emotions in this portrayed dysfunctional family and how it had followed into a second generation (Hanks life) so easily. The story flowed and the hrs drifted...i was saddened to see the blackness of the end credits appear. I think anyone who has fallen out or distanced themselves from their parents and suddenly realised perhaps things hadnt drifted as far as they had imagined ..........to have that second chance .......will love this story even more. The chemistry between Duvall and Downey Jnr is second to none. This is a great film which deserves to be watched and appreciated. E N J O Y

Review title: The Judge is a Must See
Review_body: The Judge is not merely a story about a son defending his father, who is on trial for murder, but a story about a son restoring his relationship with his father while also finding himself. The movie stars Robert Downey Jr., Robert Duvall, and Vera Farmiga. Hank Palmer (Downey Jr.) is a successful, Chicago lawyer from a small town, who left and never looked back, and if it's possible, never go back. Hank is arrogant and doesn't care if he is defending people who are obviously guilty. On top of this, he has a daughter and is in the early stages of divorce with his wife. Palmer must begrudgingly go back to his hometown of Carlinville, Indiana when he learns of his mother's death. There we find out he has a very estranged relationship with his father, who happens to be the local judge. While visiting, Hank's father, Judge Palmer (Duvall), is convicted of murdering a man he had sentenced to prison for 20 years and was recently released. Hank reluctantly agrees to represent his father, who in turn reluctantly let's his son represent him. This is not an easy case for Palmer. Throughout the movie, Hank and his father struggle to see eye to eye and to resolve their issues from the past. They both must get past their egos and pride. Hank struggles and just wants to get back to Chicago. But, while home, Hank also runs into a former girlfriend, Samantha Powell (Farmiga), who tries to help Hank get back to his roots. Hank struggles with this throughout the movie. One thing about The Judge, from a technical aspect, is it also uses lighting very well. When in Chicago as a lawyer, the use of three- point lighting makes this realm bright and feel almost fake. While in Carlinville, the use of natural and key-lighting is more predominant, making the scenes feel more realistic. This is also shown well in the respective courtrooms. In the Chicago courtroom, the use of three-point lighting makes it feel more cheery for Hank, as though he has the power here and he doesn't care about his clients. But in the Carlinville courtroom the use of low-key lighting makes the room darker and shows the seriousness of the situation, as though Hank feels he has no power, and the case actually means more to him than just a paycheck. The Judge is an excellent movie, with Downey Jr. doing what he does best: using sarcasm to make light of situations. Downey Jr. excels in the role of Hank Palmer and is becoming a modern icon. When he is in a film he seems to take over. His characters are similar, but he excels at them and does them so well, it doesn't matter. The Judge shows the struggles of a man who has to swallow his pride and try to cooperate with his father, while in the process of trying to rebuild that broken relationship and trying to get back to his roots, all the while dealing with different personal dilemmas along the way.

A great cinematic depiction of the interplay of distinctly different human emotions! Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr clearly taking the limelight, gleaming brilliance in acting by portraying an interesting murder investigation on the backdrop of a family drama. Hate, rage, pride and self obsession, to love, tenderness, forgiveness and family harmony; there is nothing to dislike about this masterpiece. The father/son saga will surely strike a cord with the audience. Vera Farmiga and Vincent D'Onofrio also shine in their characters. Overall, a must see for believers in the good old cinema that thrives on emotion and drama.

Review title: Absolutely Loved This Movie on so many levels!
Review_body: Luckily I'm not some famous critic judging movies for a living. If I listened to every critic or many who think they are movie critics, just like food critics, I would miss movies that are personally for me some of my favorites.This movie was so underrated. Absolutely brilliant. Hits ya right in the feels. Amazing! Amazing actors, excellent script, great chemistry between the actors, well edited and funny at times.The cast of Robert Downey, Robert Duvall, Billy Bob Thornton, Vera Farmiga & Dax Shepard did a great job. Great flick. Not sure why it had a 7.5 IMDb rating. I thought it was much better... and some great laughs with some great lines in it.Overall... it touched on family a lot, which was very appealing. Basically the good, the bad and the ugly regarding family. I thought it was well played out and written.

Review title: Thank you for making this film
Review_body: I rarely ever contribute to IMDB. But this particular movie has compelled me to take out the time and pen together a review. Its screenplay, its storyline and most importantly its performances are par excellence. I particularly enjoyed watching Robert Downey Jr - a truly gifted actor whose talents are being grossly under utilized.The father - son duo (played by Robert Duvall and Downey Jr) are at ideological odds. Matters are further complicated by the fact that the father blames his son (Downey Jr) for a mishap that destroys the career prospects of the older son (D'onofrio). Their relationship is messy and the excessively harsh, grating taunts of the father does not help make things any better. The caustic words continue to do its damage but the overwhelming bond between father and son remains unshakeable. And it is this bond that keeps compelling them to continuously try to bridge the gulf between them.I resonated with this movie because of my own conflicted relationship with my father. How Hank feels about his father is very similar to my own feelings about my dad. Watching Downey Jr's character Hank struggle to put past events behind, to try desperately to put together his relationship with his father and fail over and over again, to want desperately to not care and yet be unable to walk out, to overcome the simultaneous bitterness and love that he feels towards his father provided a strong sense of catharsis to me. Its as if I can see my own emotions being portrayed by Downey Jr.Its tremendously heart warming - a must see if you too are burdened by unresolved issues with your parents, if you too have a hate-love relationship with them.The Judge is a story about real life characters dealing with real life issues. It provides a refreshing change from all those superhero movies that are being produced by the dozens. Really wish RDJ would consider making more of these. Do not give it a miss.

This is a really lovely little film. The performances are great, particularly Robert DuVall who anchors the story. Also, a great family film about real life vs. super heroes and anarchy. Worth a night in. Find it.

Review title: Movie with potential but something is missing
Review_body: Watched recently. Love RDJ , role made for him. The judge himself also great acting. However it seemed bit forced and overdone.the last court scene a bit dramatic but ceased to impress.

It's a very touching story. Incredible acting. Father- Son relationship and court drama. Everything was nicely potrayed. A must watch movie for adults. People who has gone through family struggles would really love this movie. This movie really show the family is above everything. No matter how much money you have, Having a good family is always a blessing. I watched this movie so many times and still love watching it. Rare to see this kind of movies. :)

Highly gripping from start to finish. Tears at your heart as you see the crippling effects of cancer on the Judge.Robert Downey Jr. is perfect in this role as the Defense council.Soft ending which I appreciated immensely.
Absolutely excellent. RD Jr. Perfectly encompasses his character. Emotional, funny, and thrilling!

I rarely review movies but I felt compelled to review this movie to defend it from critics who have absolutely no understanding of this movie. I've always wondered what would happen if a critic were to produce and direct a movie, it would be a catastrophe!This movie is not a courtroom thriller. Not even close. It is an emotional drama with a stellar cast. The judge is a beautiful story exploring complex relationships on the premise of a courtroom. If you wanted iron man to put on his suit and destroy something you're not getting any of that.Please watch this movie!

Review title: A touching, unique film about father and son
Review_body: The Judge is a touching drama film about a father and son that is presented in a light that we have not really seen before. This relationship is an amazing driving force for the film, with performances from Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr. that are incredibly touching, thought-provoking and a joy to watch.The film is slightly let down by the directing; there are 'dramatic' elements that are unnecessary and take away from the beautiful, well-grounded emotion at the core of the film. At times, there is pretentiousness through over-reliance on music and editing. But overall The Judge is a story about pride that contains an insightful, possibly frightening, but definitely therapeutic examination of family relations. A well written script that is supported by fantastic performances makes this well worth a watch.

Review title: Duvall and Downey Jr are Magic!
Review_body: This movie clearly is among the best movies I have ever seen. Duvall has a long and outstanding career and this is one that can be seen as the cherry on top! He may have been a tiny bit off his game in a few scenes but even with a slip he is head and shoulders above the majority of today's actors. Robert Downey Jr. has always been entertaining and very good but I think he has shown he is quite capable of any role he desires from here on out. The theater was full of mostly forty-plus couples and the tears and sniffles were coming from more men than women (though they did quite a bit themselves) I think a lot of men today revisited their relationship with their own father/son. I loved this movie and will definitely see it again.

Review title: This film moved me. I cried like a baby.
Review_body: I love this film. Yes it's cliched, yes you've probably watched a film like this before but it's like an old pair of shoes, instant classic, hits all the right notes and for my mind, for all the right reasons. If you have a heart and I know that you do, you'll love this film.

Review title: An Excellent mixture of Emotions and Reality.
Review_body: As Summary of the movie suggests lead character of the movie finds the truth of his Father's Case. But for me the movie was all about the Father and son's relationship. Courtroom drama builds interest and the emotional part connects you to the the Characters. Pace is good as a courtroom drama and keeps you engaged. It touches the fine line for the perfectly entertaining emotional drama and overly bored one. Character of Duvall(the Father) is highlight of the movie. Give this movie 20 minutes and it will take you to the end in no time. Giving it generous 8/10, as a big fan of father son relationship movies and seen a good one .

What happens when you go back to that small town that was home? Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr.) reluctantly goes back home to honor his mother at her death and faces the battles that he strategically retreated from when he went to college. This film takes an unmitigated look at Midwestern family life from the point of view of the returning son. Prodigal or survivor? The disputes and other scenes of life are realistically represented with Hank facing his father, Joseph, and the rest of the town the way every battle-hardened small-town returnee would love to do. The strong disputes and unflinching negotiations that Hank and Joseph go through lead to an imperfect peace. Robert Duvall does a superb job of portraying Hank's father. Where others would let Hank soften under his father's pressure and training, Robert Downey Jr. keeps Hank strong and sharp. In his best role yet, Robert Downey Jr. shows us that he has matured into one of the solid actors working today. You will see them both at the Oscars. The Judge is one of those rare films that tell a strong story without selling out to the usual Hollywood exaggerations. I saw this movie at TIFF through the eyes of a small-town daughter who made her break to the city to get out from under the strong influence of her father. This film evoked the strong emotions that I keep buried. Thank you Robert Duvall, Robert Downey Jr., and every individual involved for giving a voice to people like me! Thank you Robert Downey Jr. for keeping Hank strong with a good heart. The Judge will prove to be a classic. See it! You will be glad you did.

Robert Downey Jr.'s ability to communicate realness continues to touch the human or iron heart. Each time he portrays this character who has serious youthful transgressions, he steps away from this artist's real life and expands the space between it and this talent he has to impress us.Duvall is tough and brilliant as expected, but believably vulnerable.Billy Bob fits the ironic 'justice is evil' part so well. He's SO good and entertaining at what he does. The pretty blue eyed girl, Vera Farmiga who plays Sam, is so fresh and mature and beautiful. In fact, each actor is allowed to bring their own creativity to this movie- to this age-old idea of a movie: the unfortunate family dynamic. It's a beauty. Don't miss it. Don't even wait.

RDJ does it again. This film is as real as it gets. The relationship between father is son is always a difficult one and this film shows that. The acting is incredible with Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall, as Robert Downey Jr seems to continue to get better and better with age. Supporting actors Vera Farmiga, Billy Bob Thornton, and Vincent D'Onofrio did a very good job as well. I went into watching this with moderate expectations and came out extremely happy after watching it and enjoyed it immensely. If you enjoy great acting, you will love this film. It is definitely up there as one of the top films of 2014 if not the very best of them all.
Loved the script and acting. Very touching film that says a lot more than law.

Review title: Great acting. Basic story line is good.
Review_body: Watching the movie six years after its release. The acting was top notch among the main characters. Glad to see Robert Downey Jr. put up a great performance as the Marvel Universe seems to have wasted his talent. Robert Duvall is also excellent - reminds me of his Tender Mercy performance.My only complaint is the excess plot of new old love interest. Writer could have explore more about Downey's failing marriage and perhaps links it to the father / son relationship. Adding that element really interrupt the flow of the movie.Great acting performances need to be treasured with great story line as they are few and far between in the recent movie making. As I enjoy trilogy action movies once in the while, industry needs to balance it more with this type of movies.

This movie seems to be a court room drama but actually it is more than that. Robert Downey Jr and Robert Duvall gave us great performances of a father( who is judge) and a lawyer son. movie introduces all characters in firs 30 minutes of movie and therefore we believe their relationships. Then main parts of movie begins and as a viewer, I couldn't stop watching and enjoying movie. As I wrote Robert Downey Jr showed great performance. although his role was basically his role on Iron Man but it fits in The Judge.Also Robert Duvall gave us another great performance as expected. I cant believe how Academy, critics and some viewers didn't gave this movie the attention that it deserved.

Review title: This movie is on my top 10 list.
Review_body:
This movie is great, it exposes the real life most of us live, the relationship between fathers and sons nowadays, and the different perspectives through different generations.
Actors went beyond greatness!! one of the masterpiece scenes is the moment "Holocene" - the sound track - was played in the background while they were all watching their childhood memories together.
this movie - for me - is one of a kind drama that is worth to be seen.

An interesting look at family dynamics and the complex results of emotionally driven decisions, a heart rendering but not soapy father-son relationship salvage, and some strong performances, not the least of which was Vincent D'Onofrio's, a repressed, inarticulate portrayal of familial love trumping drowned dreams.Yes, RDJ and Duvall were very good, but it's D'Onofrio's I will remember. What that actor can say with his sad/hopeful eyes and tightened lips...

I don't usually post reviews on movies but this movie I just had to. The movie itself is nothing less than remarkable, from the beginning to the end. For an actor who has been self-proclaimed by the Iron Man movies, Robert Downey Jr shows us the talent of an Oscar winning performance through the movie The Judge.Robert Downey Jr portrayal of a lawyer (Hank) presents a different side to Downey from the Stark role we are used to seeing on the big screen. From looking at the cover of this movie and the trailer I didn't know what to expect when I was watching this movie. Hank (Robert Downey Jr) experiences ups and downs with his family, his marriage and the people of his past life. Downey creates a more mature and A+ grade standard to his acting that we have never seen before.I don't think I could've picked a better movie to watch and highly recommend this movie to any person. If Robert Downey Jr doesn't win an Oscar for this performance I'll personally hand deliver him one myself.
There is absolutely no reason this movie should've had incest, had absolutely nothing to do with the story other than make you feel sick

I don't know what is Robert Downey, Jr's fav from his own works but out out all the movies he has done this is the best one. Every successful kid should watch this movie and see how our ego destroyed long standing relationship with our parents. Full 10 marks to David for the direction and full marks to Robert Downey.
I am a movie buff and this one of my fav movie independent of genres

I always read Reviews never actually wrote one.This movie made me write it. I really don't know what to say , there are some movies that just leave you going mad over liking them about talking about them. The more you see them the more you think of them, this one probably tops that list of movies in my opinion. A timeless classic.Great cast, Better acting. The intensity of the movie makes you go crazy. This movie is not for the faint of the heart.One of the few movies which made me cry. I recommend everyone to surely watch it. Review title: A Touching Story about Family and Redemption
Review_body: This is a touching and emotional movie about the bonds we have with our family, our roots, and what is truly important in life.Definitely not just a legal drama, although as you would except with a title like "Judge", there are a few courtroom scenes. Those are non-technical and are cut to a minimum actually. The real story and bulk of the movie is about family and coming with grips of who you are and what you stand for in life.Great, great acting by Robert Duvall (almost perfect) and not bad acting by Robert Downey Jr. I generally like Robert Downey Jr, yet his representation of the character here was a bit flat in some scenes, but powerful and very convincing in other scenes.I gave this movie a 9 mostly for the storyline and flow, and also for the powerful acting. Some scenes were drawn out and the acting wasn't perfect hence the -1.A beautiful movie in my opinion. I guess the story just struck a chord with me.

It is an original story from the director David Dobkin and Robert Downey Jr's words say it all "it's a modern tale of conflict, judgment, death, regret, irony, family dysfunction, hilarity, and of course, unconditional love". It goes way beyond a courtroom drama, it's about family, showing up for uncomfortable things, it's about not leaving things unsaid, and seeking for redemption, for forgiveness.It works so well that the most accurate comparison I can do is to an orchestra, each element of this cast is a brilliant musician with a unique instrument, and together they created the most sublime melody, so revelatory, unforgettable. This is art imitating life as it is, and people can relate with it because life is messy, people are not flawless, in real life there's no perfect way to deal with what happens to you. So whoever you are, wherever you are, you will be touched by this story, it will make you think and realize that if there's something you need to correct in your life, now is the right time.This is something different, something special, it's a great drama with great laughs, there's a lot of wit and heart in it, and we all hope to see more movies like this in the future. It's also the first movie produced by Team Downey and like Downey's character says, "Oh, we are not done", in fact this is just the beginning, an amazing takeoff for Team Downey.

Review title: A nearly perfect movie... film schools should make THIS one their study...
Review_body: I cannot remember a more satisfying movie experience, on every level. No CGI, no straining for avant garde cinematography, just perfect casting, writing, editing, acting, lighting, music, direction... If this movie isn't nominated for at least 5 categories, the powers that be are idiots... Or have forgotten the sheer joy of a dramatic story honestly presented. Duvall brings his best that we have all become accustomed to, and Downey redefined himself as an actor in my eyes. Wow. The way the director paces and develops the story line is exquisite. You can't imagine hardly a change in the casting, the actors are mostly perfect and nuanced in their roles. This film explores the scope of the human heart without being sappy or maudlin or trying too hard. Just go see this movie.

Review title: Deep drama, with periodic comic relief
Review_body: Some features of this movie seem hardly original: a legal eagle with slick tricks up his sleeve; a marriage on the rocks because one partner's mind is more on the career than on the family; a spark-laced encounter with an old high-school sweetheart right around that magical 20-year mark; and, finally, a dysfunctional family around which everything else revolves.Yes, there are clichés present in this movie. Their presence may, however, make it easier for us to follow both plot and character development; the clichés may be justifiable as devices to support a narrative that turns out to be much more complex, nuanced, and ambiguous as it unfolds, facet by facet.Front and center, of course, are father and son: Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) and Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr.). Other than both being officers of the court, they couldn't be more different from each other. Joseph is a principled judge with some of a holier-than-thou attitude, about which he feels right most of the time. Hank is a well-versed defense attorney with a somewhat unscrupulous finesse in making his case—as is necessary at times to get his client the most lenient sentence possible, if not an acquittal.And then Joseph suddenly stands accused of murder. He retains an attorney who really only moonlights as a lawyer, and who soon is in way over his head. Hank somewhat reluctantly takes it upon himself, then, to defend his father at trial.Sois Joseph guilty? When testifying in court, is he telling the truth? The movie slowly reveals and explores the demons Joseph is grappling with. One of these demons is a liability from Joseph's past and points to a motive for his alleged crime. Another of these demons is quite recent and might tarnish Joseph's legacy on the bench, regardless of the verdict.Meanwhile, Hank is grappling with demons of his own. These demons, dormant for a number of years, are now all the more virulent, now that Hank is on a forcedly prolonged stay in his hometown. Again, the movie takes time to uncover these demons in their intricacies.One of these demons is unrelenting in haunting both him and his older brother, Glen (Vincent D'Onofrio). Another has to do with his high-school sweetheart, Samantha (Vera Farmiga). Samantha, in turn, lives a lie she has been telling her daughter, Carla (Leighton Meester). This lie has a connection back to Glen, who isn't aware but would be if it weren't for Samantha's lie.So who, then, is to be "The Judge" of another? This movie illustrates how people have flaws, and therefore make mistakes that have long-term consequences. This movie shows that, even after the trial has ended, the consequences imposed by the system can be mitigated by compassion, the part of the human condition that atones for its critical flaws.And compassion is what the audience may legitimately have for both Joseph and Hank. Both are forever changed by confronting the unprecedented challenges in the turn of events. Neither Joseph nor Hank—nor anyone else, for that matter—can be readily filed under "good" or "evil." If all was not "well done," most was still "well-intended." It comes as no surprise that it is Robert Duvall's superb acting that facilitates this takeaway from the movie. The character of Joseph Palmer requires incredible stretches in the portrayal of a man with both sharp intellect and cognitive impairment, and both wiry stature and decrepit physique.So who, then, is to be "The Judge" of another? This movie shows different judgments passed in the court of law versus the court of public opinion. The former centers on certain actions, the latter centers on totality of character. And the way the story is told, in the end it is the court of public opinion that has it right.

Duvall's testimony was as good a courtroom scene as has ever been filmed, and technically accurate, too. (I say this from 32 years as a trial lawyer.) Beautifully directed. I am biased in favor of Duvall, but I think both he and Downey are in the running for an Oscar for this must-not-miss movie. The movie itself might even be nominated for the Best Movie Oscar. For those who think this was a tearjerker, reflect on how profoundly life-changing it is to grow into adulthood without your father's approval -- or worse, with his active disapproval. The complexities of the sibling relationships is honest and painful and, in the case of the youngest brother, tender. The cherry on top is Downey's parting observation in the men's room to the federal prosecutor about the "miracle" of 12 average people coming together and doing justice. This is a true thing and is part of how the American justice system has managed to survive.

Watching this film, and reading a series of reviews, has taught me something i thought i already understood but now is already crystal clear.When you are watching a film, and you want to analyze it, there are tons of thing you can think of: the cinematography was great, the music was excellent, the script is amazing, the cast and their performances are marvelous, the director's view is clear, etc... And that is one of the great things of Art, it is so great that you can find a million persons and every single one of them would tell you something different about the movie, and at the end of the day, that's what matters the most, if you like it or not.When "The Judge" credits started going down, i thought "Man, this may be one of the best movies of year", then i went to some reviews sites and start realizing that a lot o people were saying that the movie was to long, that it was a living cliché, that it was a poorly made court drama film, and as i said before, there is no problem in either if you hate it or love it, but just don't hate it for the wrong reason. The cinematography was great, you can immediately get the truly celluloid look and the tone they were looking for with great placed lighting, the score was accord to the movie, it was not overwhelming and it drive us perfectly in what is the main theme of the movie, WHICH IS NOT A JUDGE ON TRIAL FOR MURDER, if not the relationship between a father and his son, behind that there is trial, that works as our transport in this emotional growth that each character has, emotional growth that is perfectly performed by this two great actors which should be both at least nominated for the Academy, the script and passing are good, there is no way in that you could put every movie in a 90 pages script, some times you just have to tell more to show the story in the way you want to show it. This movie is touching, realistic and well told. I know this is not the most original idea in the movies universe, but that doesn't turn it in to a Cliché. Guillermo Del Toro once said that every movie story is already told, what matter is the way in that you tell it, and it can't be more true. No matter what film you see in this days, i'm 100% sure that if you look in the past, you'll find at least one that has the very same base story, what changes is the way in that it is being told to you. If you think like that, ¿every movie would be a cliché don't you think?, I don't think so. I'm a 18 years old Film student and i've watch a lot of films, and at least for me, there has being a long time since a movie show us this kind of son-father relationship and emotional growth in such a touching way, this is by far one of the greatest movies of the year and you should not hesitate while thinking if it worth your time or not. It truly does.

Review title: Our Audience Applauded at the End
Review_body: I rarely see a movie on its opening night. but we made the exception for this movie. We are not professional film critics, nor are we filmophiles, as some of the people who regularly post here seem to fancy themselves... We are just regular, normal, everyday people, and we really liked this film. Was it long? Yes, but this is the first movie I have watched in a while that didn't have me walk out wondering why something seemed to be missing from the story. This is a feeling I usually attribute to studio pressure that filmmakers present a finished product that comes in under the 2 hour mark... Something ends up on the cutting room floor - usually the part I wondered about.I loved Robert Duvall's performance, and he is not an actor I have ever really liked. His character is going through so much, and I watched that play out at the hands of a very excellent actor. I would like to see Robert Downey Jr. In a film where he doesn't have to be the whip smart, always ready with the perfect comeback, character. The parts of this movie where you see his portrayal of someone with more depth were very, very good. Unfortunately, he will probably not be recognized for that because his usual character type actions/dialogue tends to overshadow the other.I have seen lots of professional reviews that did not like this movie. However, while we did not do this, at the end of the movie, when the credits began to roll, applause broke out in the theater. This impressed me, because other than at the occasional sci-fi movie attended by fan boys, I cannot remember ever going to a movie where the majority of the audience expressed their appreciation this way.Go see it. I do think that Robert Duvall will likely get an Academy Award nomination for this role.

Review title: A healthy change that will take getting used to.
Review_body: Needing a break from software development, Ebola, and Kickstarter: I went to see the movie "The Judge" and left not sure whether I liked it or not.Reflecting on that, this is what I think happened:Many of use are familiar with changing something we are accustomed to, a healthier alternative, but change isn't easy. Such as going from using sugar in our coffee to drinking it black. It just takes time to adjust.Hollywood has routinely portrayed and romanticized the anti-hero. We've grown used to this fare. However, the anti-hero story is always rendered in a flash of time. The arrogance, drug use, womanizing, what-have-you always looks glamorous and fun. Realistically, if these behaviors were shown over a larger time-span, the results wouldn't be nearly as pleasant."The Judge" stars Robert Downey Jr, playing Hank Palmer, a prototypical anti-hero, a role Downey plays so well. However, it shows him over the course of growing up as a child into mid-life. The behavior that we've grown to like when depicted over a week or a month, is suddenly less appealing.It is realistic and healthy though. This is probably the most moral movie to have come out of Hollywood in years. A healthy change that will take some getting used to.

If you see one movie this year (and I know it's almost over), you have to see THE JUDGE! What a cast! The story is solid and well developed. Duvall and Downey, Jr. are phenomenal together and the supporting cast rocked it. I cried, I laughed, I was enthralled. I'd see this movie again in a heartbeat. I recently saw Gone Girl and left wanting. You definitely would feel that way with THE JUDGE. I'm not going to tell you the story as I'm sure you get the gist from the trailers. But the trailers don't do the film justice. This is the best film I've seen in a very long time. Downey, Jr. is soooo good! Duvall is the best! Go see it today!

Review title: Fine example of a well produced film
Review_body: Robert Downey and his wife Susan Downey have hit a home run with this picture. They understand that most of the events in any life are accidental or arbitrary, especially the crucial ones, and we can exercise little conscious control over our destinies. They understand that the "Judge" and his lessons were about how to behave no matter what life brings; about how to wade into the unpredictable court of law and deal with whatever happens with grace, courage and honesty. It is the film's best achievement that it communicates that message with such feeling.The relationships portrayed were superbly acted by all. At one point during the movie, while wiping away a tear, I looked around the theater and saw dozens of people around me doing the same. This movie was a treasure for many reasons, but the best one, I think, is that I could believe it. I could believe in its major characters and their relationships, and in the things they felt for one another, and there were moments when the movie was witness to human growth and change. I left the theater feeling good and warm, and with a certain resolve to try to mend my own relationships and learn to start listening better . . . watching the movie, I felt I was witnessing something rare and valuable.

I signed up to IMDb just to say that, in my humble opinion, this'll end up being one of those much-loved movies the critics simply got wrong. It took a little while (15 minutes or so) to sink its teeth into me but once it did I was captivated. At the beginning I found it hard to get a handle on the tone of the film, which by the end I loved. I was expecting a playful film with some seriousness thrown in but it's really a serious film with some playfulness/humour peppered throughout too - in just the right way, and just the right amount. Once I realised this I went along with it (whereas at the start I'd thought it was taking itself a bit too seriously). It goes without saying that the performances are top notch (and not just the main two actors but the handful of others too). Overall, a great film. A really great film. Definitely worth checking out in my opinion.

Review title: Best acting i have seen in a very long time/!!!
Review_body: The Judge starts with an interesting premise. Good characters with underlying currents of sibling envy and a struggle for dads approval. Hats off to the writers. Great casting/!!! Great acting from the entire cast!! Jeremy Strong did a great job of the little brother that just wanted to see healing come to his family. Downey-Duvall combo was riveting/!!! Duvall is, of course, a master. Downey is like a fine wine--getting better all the time --maturing his Craft/!!!! I haven't enjoyed a movie this much in a long time -- not a lot of glitz and facade but just a good story supported by excellent acting--the stuff of which classics are made!!! Definitely Academy Award worthy!!!!

Review title: forget the critics reviews, watch the judge, if you want to watch an incredibly special film, which happens to have a stellar cast
Review_body: Soo, was initially hesitant as well as excited to watch this film. Hesitant after reading some of the unfavorable critic reviews labeling the film as 'cliched','formula', simply praising the performances of Downey Jnr & Duvall. Excited because well, I'm a fan of courtroom dramas & when you have epic actors like Downey Jnr & Duvall in a film together, I really don't need another reason to see the filmAfter watching The Judge, I can clearly say all my preconceptions and assumptions got blown out of the window, along with the unfound negative criticism it received. Contrary to belief the film is not simply a formula films, Yes the story of a cut throat city lawyer turning ethical to save his dad from prison, may appear to be a bit seen-their-done-that. This is simply the topping of the film. The film is richly layered with a plethora of stories, genres & relationships, generously intertwined into this story. The delicate way the film handles the complex strained relationship between son & his father, as well as his siblings is one of the finest & most honest portrayal I've seen (and I've probably watched almost every estranged son-father film made). Most of all its an honest yet entertaining film. Its brave enough to not fall into a Disney fairytale ending, of many courtroom and dysfunctional family film. It has the guts to stay true to the story, its characters & the reality of when you have a family broken in many ways trying to function. The protagonist doesn't run off with his high school sweet heart into the sunset, nor does he manage to pull of a courtroom miracle to stop his father going to prison with his incredible lawyer skills, nor does his father doesn't jump into his arms at the end. YET it is still is a film which leaves you with hope & redemption. How David Dobkin created a film of this nature is truly a miracle. Its not a film which relies on its stellar cast to keep it running This is genuinely a great film in all aspects, screenplay, story, acting & direction. Like myself you may just initially see this film purely to see Downey Jnr & Duvall, but I warn you, you will end up seeing a great film

Review title: Robert Downey Jr. and Robert Duvall capture something beautiful in "The Judge"
Review_body: "The Judge" is a failure in a lot of ways. It takes on too many stories at once and leaves most of them hanging–with no end in sight. The movie tries too hard to win an Oscar, and it's loosely held together by a fantastic father-son relationship with two star actors: Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr.The movie starts with Robert Downey Jr. pissing on a lawyer and ends with him looking at a chair. It involves an incestuous drunken night at a bar, a terribly outdated concert t-shirt, an awkward family and a whole lot of courtroom shenanigans with no real legal basis.The most memorable moment in the film is a scene in which Robert Duvall has explosive diarrhea all over the bathroom and the audience has the opportunity (displeasure?) of watching Robert Downey Jr. rinse said diarrhea off of his father. You could say that this scene didn't need to happen, and probably shouldn't have.But that would be missing the point. Yes, the movie has a lot of quirks. Yes, it's awkward and frustrating and leaves you with so many questions you feel like your head is going to explode. But that's the point. The film is all about the awkward, tense relationship between a hard-ass father dying of cancer and at risk of going to jail, and his not so straight-edge son. All that other stuff is just background noise to divert your attention from an on-screen relationship that could make even the most reserved man cry. The emotional appeal is what it's really all about. The other stuff–the renewed relationship with a past lover (and brief escapade with her daughter), the impending divorce and the strain that puts on a little girl, and perhaps most significantly, Robert Downey Jr. playing his typical role: a rich asshole–all provides comic relief from something that would be far too emotionally intense to sit through. And to the critics who argue that the film would fail if not for the star performances of Robert Duvall and Robert Downey Jr., you are completely off base. When the main focus of the film is to examine such an intense, strained relationship, then shouldn't the highlight of the film be the performances of those two actors? Yes–if not for those two performances the film would be awful. It would fail to hold the attention of the audience, and it certainly would not make the tears flow. But why is that a bad thing? Shouldn't we praise the movie for what it gets right? Because never before has a father and son relationship been captured so beautifully on screen.So should you go see two men named Robert hash out their differences on-screen? Absolutely–but don't forget to bring the tissues.

It took a little bit before I was drawn completely in, but once I was, I was hooked! Love the actors, love the story...I laughed, I cried. It warmed my heart. I WILL own this movie when it comes out on video. I went back to see it again with my teenage sons and once the movie was over, my 17 year old turned to me and said, "That was easily one of the best movies I've ever seen." It's a story of the misunderstanding, fear, frustration, love, hope, and forgiveness that comes with having a family. Downey and Duvall gave unmatched performances. If I wasn't already a fan, this would have made me one for both of these amazing actors. The supporting cast was perfect as well. Kudos to RDJ and his wife, Susan on their Team Downey Production Company's first major endeavor. I can't wait for more! My mother was just in town and I took her to see it as soon as she got here. I refused to let her miss it. She loved it too. Thank you, RDJ for making such a wonderful movie about redemption.

Wheres my Bit-O-Honey old man. The writers and producers perfectly placed the right cast together to make one of the most heartfelt creations of a movie that I have seen in a very long time, an all star cast who all brilliantly brought life, gave birth to a touching passionately powerful script. Ask any son who has a father who was hard and very disciplinary towards a son about the struggle and resentfulness one feels and growing up to form a lost bond in the last days of his fathers life, if you are lucky enough to get that time to reconcile differences between each other just how special that is, take it from experience I have and I am sure there are others that have. Such a great movie. It was an honest movie the whole way through. Very believable and easy to get lost in this movie. Wonderfully directed, superb story line, and perfect acting/casting. If you don't like this movie and it doesn't touch you in some way, than you have some bad taste in movies and no feeling. This story is about 3 boys whose father is a judge. One son is a lawyer and goes home when he hears about the death of his mother. The father and son never really got along for certain reasons that you will find out later, which is why he moved away from home. When the son is home it brings up some fond old memories and also some bad memories. The father is accused of a hit and run and the son defends him, that's all I can really say without giving anything away. This is not just a movie were everything takes place in the courtroom and drags along. It has a good beginning, middle, and a good realistic ending. You'll be happy you watched it.

Review title: I would have liked to see a more sinister plot
Review_body: There were good actors and good acting, but the plot line was dry as a bone. I kept thinking there was going to be a sinister twist to the plot and I even thought I had it figured out and was ready to pat myself on the back for being so clever ;) It goes something like this: Judge Joseph Palmer (Robert Duvall) was framed by Prosecutor Dwight Dickham (Billy Bob Thornton) because the long-ago defendant, Mark Blackwell (Mark Kiely) was let off his original crime with just a "spanking" of a sentence by Palmer. Of course, a short time after that Blackwell kills his teenage girlfriend and ended up spending the next 20 years in jail. But what I thought was going to happen next was that Hank Palmer (Robert Downey Jr.) was going to discover from a brilliant investigation (borrowing from his Sherlock Holmes skills from his other movie ^-^) that not only was Dickham Blackwell's prosecutor from his original trial, but that Blackwell's murder victim was Dickham's niece (or some other close relative). So Dickham had it in for both Palmer and Blackwell and he killed two birds with one stone (so to speak). Of course, the movie had already droned along for like 2 AND A HALF HOURS already, so it was kind of late for any such surprises.Anyhow, I didn't check the "contains spoiler" box, because this wasn't the actual plot (unfortunately). Can this movie even have a spoiler alert? Like I said, dry as a bone (but good acting!).So what do you think of my clever twist, eh? What's that, don't quit my day job? That's what I figured.

I absolutely loved this film,Robert Downey jr is such an underrated actor I think.He is soooooo good in this film showing his emotions,Robert Duvall was excellent as well.Bit of a tear jerker but really worth the watch.Robert Downey jr is a hot shot lawyer who never loses a case.When his father ,who is the judge back home is accused of murder,he steps in to defend his estranged father.I thought the acting was outstanding in this film and would definitely recommend it.It shows the tribes and tribulations that lots of families go through and how they still love each other when life gets hard.Set in Massachusetts the scenery is beautiful.

Review title: Why is RDJ acting so weird?
Review_body: This was not very pleasant. I haven't seen RDJ like this since he was on drugs. Is he on drugs again? He's almost spastic, in a not-good-Jim-Carrey-way. Too high strung, too much of everything. What happened here? Otherwise I'd say the movie is just OK.They are all doing what they are supposed to do. Duvall is maybe a little over the top. And I'm a bit tired of those streamline versions of Rainman characters, though. All people with Aspergers or autistic people don't behave in the same way.I'm giving it a 5, but I'm struggling. It's probably more like a 4. The 5 is for the love of RDJ.

Every other actor in this film, plays a vital role in explaining the dynamics of the Palmer family. I have watched this movie numerous times, and will always be one of my favorites. If you get the chance to watch The Judge, you will not be disappointed. Thank you for making this film.
